11.content:
Men

         The strength of your people is no doubt stronger than ever. Aragorn, heir to Isildur, became part of the Fellowship at the important Council of Elrond many years ago, even though he knew the lineage of his family was weak when it came to the One Ring. Yet he conquered and did not give in, proving that even though the race of men can be easily corrupted, there are some whose strength and will is fierce. Now the One Ring has been destroyed for good, and Aragorn is no longer an heir, he is a noble King, and as always, will remain a part of the race of men.

         You, too, are of the race of men. The race whose features cannot be guessed until birth, the race whose loyalties are often hard to tell, and the race whose mind can change at any moment, whether for good or evil. And as a part of the race of men, you are not necessarily born a fighter, but when you learn, you are very skilled, and your ability is fatal to those whom you fight. You fought before when Sauron's shadow was looming over Middle Earth, and once again an evil threatens to rule. You know the times have been better than ever, but you know that they will grow weary again. You know the time for resistance is now. The time for plans is now, before another evil wreaks havoc on Middle Earth again.

         This time definitely calls for defense. An evil is lurking about in Middle Earth once again. Its reign is not yet strong, but it is growing. The wicked creature that brings such hate, cruelty, and malice is clever. It is hiding far enough in shadow that its identity has not yet been seen. Yet the remaining orcs and other evil creatures that survived from Sauron's time in power have multiplied, and they have already joined forces with this unknown evil.

         As the crowd of various races seat themselves, the rooms goes silent. Elrond's voice fills the open room; you listen attentively, knowing the importance and secrecy of all of his meetings.

         "It has been a great while since I have called a council of such significance. Not since Sauron's threat to overtake Middle Earth has such an evil come unto these lands. We were fortunate enough to know of Sauron's plan to find the One Ring, and we successfully destroyed it. But with this evil, we do not know what its plans are, what it looks like, or even if it has a human form. We call upon the elves, dwarves, wizards, men, and now hobbits," Elrond says as he looks over to Frodo, "as well as any other free people of Middle Earth to defend all that is good."

          Continuing, Elrond says, "Those who are with us from the Fellowship of The Ring have already vowed to lead this quest, but they cannot do it alone. We need many of you to help, but there are probably few of you who are brave enough to do so." He pauses for a moment, with a look of concern on his face, "I will give you all a few moments to think out your decision.

Now you must make your first decision. Will you help defend all that is good in Middle Earth?

11111.content:
You have decided to trade one of your elven cloaks for one of the dwarf's swords. It is heavier than what you are used to, but it is brilliantly made, and strong, perfectly fit for any battle. You thank him as he packs up and continues on his path.
         You had planned on going on your own, for you feel you work better alone, but a man runs up behind you and kindly places his hand upon your shoulder. You turn around to see who has confronted you, and it turns out to be none other than Aragorn, the man who overcame the corruption of the One Ring those many years ago.
         "I thank you for your willingness to search for help to defeat this new evil." He begins to say, "My name is Aragorn, and..."
         "I believe it is you who deserves thanks. For your service those many years ago." You reply, "If it wasn't for you and the other companions of the Fellowship, then middle earth would not be as we know it now."
         "Well then, now it is your time to make a difference for the people of middle earth. It would be better if you didn't travel alone," Aragorn insisted.
         "You don't understand, I can do this alone," you persist.
         "Please. Say no more, come with me." Aragorn said as he led you back to where the council had been...

* * * * *


         As Aragorn lead you back into the council room, you saw that Elrond was not present at the moment. Aragorn continued to lead you, and brought you over to a seat. As he did this, you began to think about the past, and how close Sauron had come to gaining complete authority over Middle Earth.
         You realize that this undefined evil could threaten all that is good, like Sauron had, but this evil unfighted could win. You had already made your mind up, now you just had to wait and see what Elrond was going to say. The room was filled with silence as Elrond walked back in and sat down.

         "All of you who have already cowered down and decided not to help the fate of Middle Earth, please leave now, for I don't have the heart to speak to you, nor see you." Elrond ordered. When the last word departed from his lips, not a soul moved. You were surprised, yet pleased to see that everyone was willing to help.
         "I had no doubt that many of you would help, but this many is beyond belief. Certainly this is a miracle." Elrond continued, "We have little or worthless knowledge of what exactly this undefined evil is hoping to achieve. It will take more than brute strength, fighting skills, and clever manuevering with a sword, bow, and an axe to win against this evil creature, although these will help. The only thing we can use now is our minds. We must figure out more before we make our first attack. All of you will travel in groups, you will go to distant lands to uncover more information. And from there, we will get back in touch when we think we've all had enough information revealed to us. Then our strategy for attack will commence."
         Elrond paused for a moment as if he were deeply troubled. He then took a deep breath and continued.
         "Form groups of nine now. Only one group already has been decided, the Fellowship of The Ring will travel together, as they once did many years ago. Boromir is no longer with us, so one of you will travel in his place. May his legacy help you travel faster and stronger. Also, I advise you all to bring weapons with you, for we do not know where this evil creature and his followers lurk."
         After Elrond said this, you were grateful that you had traded your extra cloak for such a sturdy sword. When you glanced up from your sword, you saw Aragorn looked towards you, waiting for your decision. Were you to follow your own path, and make a group of your own? Or would you join Aragorn and the others in the Fellowship?

"I have a better idea." you say. "We'll split up and gather the members, and then we shall meet back here in an hour. Afterwards we can each prepare and we will set out tomorrow. Is that acceptable?” you ask. “Very well,” responded Aragorn. “But do not take too long.” After an exchange of nods, you both go your separate ways and you begin searching for someone you need to talk to.

After about thirty minutes of searching, by your estimate, you found Boromir preparing to leave Rivendell. “Where do you think you are going?” you shout at him. “I am making leave for Gondor; I serve no purpose staying here anymore.” Boromir answers. “Oh but you do have a purpose, in fact you have three.” You counter. He gives a chuckle, “What exactly are they?” “First, you shall go tell Elrond you will be accompanying me and the rest of the fellowship to Mordor, with his approval or not. Second, you shall meet the rest of us where OUR fellowship was established. And third, you will take the rest of the day to prepare for our journey.” You command.

“Why should I do that?” questions Boromir. “You have enough members already.” Frustrated you pin him against the wall violently, you only did this because he let you. “Listen,” you angrily whisper, “you have to go we need you. You are a better warrior than me, Elrond only denied you because he thought the Ring would corrupt you, but with me that won’t happen.” you pause. “Please…” you beg calmer, “you must, go I cannot protect them as well as-” “Alright, you have convinced me. I will do as you say.” Boromir interrupts. “Thank you. That is much appreciated” You say. “Go find the others like you were told,” says Boromir “I will join you all soon.” As he runs off, you gain a new confidence and rush out find the other members of the Fellowship of the Ring, of your fellowship.

1112111.content:
After the long journey to Rivendale, and exhausting council meeting, Daeloth headed to her room to retire for the evening. The night had been filled with memories...good and bad. In the end, Daeloth felt good to be back in the land that she had once called home.

When she was just an infant, Gandalf had entrusted her life in the hands of Lady Arwen and her father, Lord Elrond. Lady Arwen unhesitatingly answered the call of adopted mother to her. She taught Daeloth Elvish, as her first language, and taught her about earth and all its wonders and beauties. Lord Elrond took her under his wing, and bestowed upon her the knowledge of his kin in the art of potions. She leard what every weed, root, water, earth, wind, and tree had to offer in the healing relm...as well as the warrior relm. The potions she had learned could heal the sickest of creatures or kill the stronges of life form on Middle Earth.

Aragorn then entered her life in her teen years. He taught her survival, fighting, and tracking. After she spent most of her time from dawn until evening learning how to defend herself, Lady Arwen would take her and teach her how to ride stallions across the meadows of Rivendale, ever so mindful of its borders, and the enemies which waited patiently beyond for a stray victim. It was then that she became a Ranger; alone in the world.

She had made her home in a cave, with winding caversn of granite and limestone, with hot-springs pools and small cold waterfalls that prvided her a place to bathe and obtain fresh water without her having to leave the safety of her shelter in the middle of no where. The caves were located between Roehan and Isengod, near Fangon Forest. She knew most creatures feared the trees of old, but Lord Elrond had entroduced her to Treebeard when she was just a child, and asked him to help protect her if she ever straied into the trees in which he guarded. He agreed, and enjoyed Daeloth's many wonders into his forests. He enjoyed the way she climbed up his branches and swung on his vines. It tickled him, and he grew quite fond of the child, and often put her to sleep with some of his stories of the olden days when he was nuthing more than a sapling. How she longed for a ride in his branches once more, and look at the valley and mountains of Roehan just one more time.

But things were now in motions to which she could not turn back no mater what potion she concockted or how hard she prayed. She was to take the place of a Captain, a Warrior, a man in whom she had respected and loved. Boromir had wondered into her cave over fours years ago. It seemed as if it were only yesterday when she had looked into the bule eyes of the handsome Captain of Gundor; wet, half starved, and exhausted from riding. His men, of many hundreds, looked just as pitiful if not worse than he. She offered her cave with its many caverns as a place in which they could find rest, bath, and a hot meal. She had grain also in which the many horses could be nourished as their masters made rest for themselves. She had many bars of soap she had made from dried flowers and boars fat, in which she offered to the men to bathe in the hot-springs in which she had showed them. She gave wool blankets to those whose bedding was saturated from the heavy rains, or to them that had not sheild from the cold in which to warm themselves. She even offered her bed, made of chicken feathers and frames out of golden oak, to Captain Boromir; suggesting that it be she who slept the night on the floor, convincing him that she would be quite warm and comfortable in front of the warm fire.

Before the night was completed, where all the men had blankets, bathes, and a hot meal digesting in there malnourished stumaches, Daeloth had made over twenty pots of venicine stew and ten pots of chicken broth for those too sick to hold anything stronger down. She also added the doctors in treating the wounded and ill.

"Why are you doing this, my Lady?" Boromir asked.

"There was a time...when I was but a child, in which I too needed the aid of people who were not of my own kin. Without hessitation or question they took me and and saved my live, only asking in return that I too share what I have been graciously blessed with with those in need. I had meat, drink, and a warm place to sape, my Lord. Who am I to deny hungry, tired, and povrished men the comforts of medicine, water, and meal for their horses and themselves?" Daeloth explained as she put another log on the fire and mixed the red coals, which ignited the dry log.

Boromir leaned over in his chair and kissed her cheek. "I thank you, my Lady. Neither I, nor the men of Gundor, will forget your compassion and kindness in which you have showen us this day."

"How long will you be staying, my Lord?" Daeloth asked standing up and returning to her chair opposite of Boromir in front of the fire.

"I wish to leave on the morrow, but I fear the storm might prevent this. My surgeons also advise me that the men need rest, or my army will suffer losses not obtained in battle. I do not wish to impose on you..."

"Not at all, my Lord. I shall offer you all that I have. I believe in what you are doing, and will aid your efforts in protecting our borders from Orci as best I can. I do not have much, but all that I have, please feel free to use, my Lord."

Boromir and his men staied for more than three weeks, letting his men get the rest they so deserved and needed before heading out to find his brother Faomir, and attack the Orci who were trying to take ofer the White City. Those were the best weeks of Daeloth's life. She had fallen in love with him, and they were to me wed the following spring. But Boromir's destiny was not to be that shared with Daeloth. He had died before she had the chance to become his bride. After his death, she returned to her cave, not venturing out more than Fangon Forest, where she hunted for food in the protection of Treebeard.

Now she was here, in Rivendale for the first time in almost ten years, called by Lord Elrond himself. For what, she did not know until she had been chosen to take the place of Boromir in the Fellowship. These where shoes in which were too big to replace, shoes she didn't want to replace. She loved Boromir, and the thought of sitting in his chair in the Council un-nerved her to the bone. It was then she heard a knock at the door, and turned to see who it was.

"Lord Elrond would like a word with you Daeloth," smiled a blond elf as he entered the room and kissed her forehead.

"Legolas!" she cheered and she swung her arms around him like a child and hugged him. He returned her hug and smiled at her playfulness.

"You act as if you have not seen me in a decade young one," Legolas teased.

"It HAS been a decade since we have seen one another. And I'm not a little girl anymore Legolas," she reminded him with her hands on her hips.

Legolas took the a dagger out of his waistban sheath and played with its tip. "When you are as old as I, one is still a baby until they are at least fifteen hundren years old my Lady." Both smiled as Daeloth sat down on a chair next to her bed.

"Lord Elrond wants to see me?" Daeloth asked.

"Yes, as soon as you can make your way to the Great Hall," Legolas informed her.

"He asked you to come get me, did he?" she asked smiling at her old partner in crime.

"No, I volunteered," he grinned and made his way back to the door.

"I'll be right down," Daeloth said as she stood up and grabbed her map bag and slung it ofer her shoulder.

11121112.content:
Rivendale was a vast aray of orange, red, yellow, and dark green colors. The time of the Elves were to be over soon. Middle Earth would be void of the ever loving and beautiful creatures for ever. This had been Daeloth's home for many years, and now she was about to lose everything she held so dear to her. If only she has spent more time here, with her family? Why did she have to wait so long to appreciate the ones who cared for her most, to spend ten years away from Rivendale when it was entering its final days filled with Elvish life? How she longed to be a little girl, curled up in Lady Arwen's arms again, having her comb her hair and tell her stories of her and Prince Legolas growing up. How long would those beloved stories last before fading into legends and mythical tales? What about Frodo and all the adventures of the Hobbits? Would they be forgotten in time too?

All this proved to be more than Daeloth could bare. Tears began to stream down her face as she sat under Thuja, the Elf tree of life. As the tears made s-curves down her ceeks to the tip of her chin, the cool fall breeze picked up swooping her hair about her face, and causing brown crisp leaves to fall on her lap and top of her head. A gentle hand removed one of the leaves that had fallen on her head and let it go as the wind picked it up and floated it into the land somewhere else in Rivendale.

"This was always your favorite spot," a familiar voice spoke as the figure sat down beside Daeloth. "I remember the first time I lost you. I looked all over Rivendale for you, and lost all hope in finding you. Then what should I find curled up and sleeping under Thuja? You, my beloved child."

"Everything was so simple then Lady Arwen," Daeloth whimpered as she wiped her runny nose and dried her tears. "What is to become of us when the Elves leave this place?"

Arwen smiled and held her close. "We may not be here in body, but the Elf spirit shall be here, and in all of Middle Earth. As long as the humans believe in us and love one another, the Elves shall remain forever in their hearts. Besides, I shall be in Gundor with Aragorn. You will not be alone Daeloth."

"Lord Elrond is leaving. Who will heal the people of Middle Earth when he is gone? Gandalf will be gone, as well as your grandmother." Daeloth stood up and looked to the outer trees of Rivendale, where the sunlight beamed through the leaves, shining rays of light here and there on the green grass covering the floor of Rivendale. "What is to become of us all...what is to become of the Fellowship?"

"Only time will tell. As long as we bind ourselves together in unity, friendship, and love, there will be peace in Middle Earth. When greed, hatred, and bitterness invades our hearts, then all we have worked and died for will be lost. The world will then change, and on that day will the Elves truly leave Middle Earth, for they can not abide in wickedness," Arewn explained as she too stood up beside Daeloth.

"What must I do now? I have not yelded a sword in years!" Daeloth prtested.

Arwen smiled. "Well, standing around here pouting is not going to help your battle skills, my darling."

111211121.content:
Daeloth opened the door to the High-Elven Camber where Lord Elrond stayed. He was leaning over a number of maps, books, journals, and she even thought she might have seen a glimpse of what appeared to be old Bilbo and darling Frodo's book! Not wanting to disturb her Grandfather from his deep meditation, she stepped ever so lightly across the room and stood behind him. Her foot steps were as light as a cool wind blowing across a meadow of green spring grass on a warm day. Her presence sent a rush of warmth over Elrond, and he turned to take her hand into his, and he kissed it with his lips ever so gently.

"You wanted to see me, Grandfather?" Daeloth asked.

"You are comforting to me. How I've missed the little girl who I use to catch hiding under Thuja!" he said standing up and embracing her. "Come, we have much to talk about." He led her to a couch made of woven willow and lush green reeds, with pillows laid upon it.

"What are you feeling?" he asked

"I feel...empty; like a newly constructed home with no tenants to claim me," she answered looking out the window into the city of Rivendell.

"Empty? Is that all that troubles you?" he perused. Elrond had a way of looking into the eyes of a person and telling the utter most secrets of the soul. He counted it as a blessing, and at times a curse. He was glad to know when one was trying to be deceitful, yet heavy laden when noticing the hint of betrayal by one he held dear. But, Elrond had lived many years of men and Elves. He knew that in this day and age one could not rely on just feelings alone. One must use the knowledge gained in life to decipher the good with the bad. One must weigh the cost of all choices and their consequences. Elves had a very good way of doing this; seldom offering advice to one without giving them both a yes or no answer. In the end, the Elves knew the decider must choose his own path in which to travel; for Elves, for the most part, did not concern themselves with the worries nor the cares of men. But this was his adopted grand-daughter. He cared for her as much as Arwen and Aragorn did. In a way, he had wished she did not volunteer to take Boromir's place.

Elrond knew Daeloth was more than capable in taking Boromir's place, yet he wanted to protect her. It wasn't like Arwen, who was given the grace of immortality when born. Daeloth was born of men and therefore a mortal life. The thought of loosing her of old age was hard enough to dwell upon then the fact that she could be killed at any moment along the way to the age of wisdom. In the end, Elrond knew that Daeloth did not end up in the Fellowship by chance; like Frodo and the One Ring. There was a purpose to everything; for the universe held a great balance.

"It’s Boromir. I keep thinking about him...about what could have been...should have been. How am I to rid my dreams of him, and yet be known as the one who has taken his place? I wish I could just return to my cave and not deal with such matters." Daeloth put her hands over her eyes and began to rub them. She was weary with thinking. Everything was changing for her. She had known this day would come, but felt insecure in herself. She wasn't sure she could be strong enough to be what was expected of her. Oh, she was physically and mentally strong enough. But her emotions were still that of one who had lost their mate.

"Boromir was a good man, Daeloth. He loved you with all his heart, and I would have been proud to have bid him son. But that was not his fate. The Ring had chosen what was to be to be in the end. He died with honour. You must morn him for the man he was my child, but don't live to morn. There is another path your life has taken. One that even I can not entirely see. Boromir will always be with you, for his spirit abides in those that loved him the most. He will watch out for you and come to you in dreams and visions to keep you from all evil. Trust in his, and do not morn his death, but rejoice in his life among the Elves of old who have departed these lands long ago. For he dwells in a new Fellowship now; one that can never be defeated!" Elrond rose from the couch and went back to his table of maps, books, and journals. "Come, I have something to show you."

Daeloth took back her wondering thoughts and tucked them deep inside her heart for now. She then rose and met Elrond at the table. On it laid open an old map of tunnels that appeared to lie beneath Middle Earth. Each tunnel seemed to have and entrance and an exit in some type of earthly vegetation or natural landmark. In some places, there were little towns and villages circled in red ink upon the map. On other parts of the map, there were places of refuge that Daeloth had been shown before when she was young by Elrond circled in green ink. At the top right hand corner of the map was a small drawing of a sceptre which contained an odd coloured jewel.

"This is a map of concern for the Fellowship. I have circled the places in red which I have seen in my dream, which appear to be place of uncertainty and mistrust. It is in these places your guard must be at full alert. The ones in green are allies to the Elves and Aragorn. If you need rest, trust these folk; for they would give their lives for the safety of our people, and those in whom the Elves call friend," Elrond advised.

"What is this?" Daeloth pointed to the picture at the top of the map.

Elrond walked around to the other side of the table and poured himself a cup of water and began to take a drink. The cool water was refreshing to him, as he took his seat. "That is the Sceptre of Edlairth, given to the first wizard born to Middle Earth by the Half-Elves. It is most powerful, and in the wrong hands could be more powerful, more dangerous than the Ring that was cast into Mount Doom. It is this that the Fellowship and the other unified groups of the council must obtain and bring back to Lothlorien! There is much evil that still strides upon Middle Earth. With the Elves leaving the shores to set sail to the East, we must get this sceptre back and it too must go with us on our journey."

"What are all these other papers about? Is this all about the sceptre?" she asked flipping through the papers.

"No. There are other things that must be taken with us. A book of Elendil, the Grail of the Elements, and the Star of Thoure must all too be found and taken with us. Each have been used by the Elves to control potions to cure the sick, but can be used to cause death; used to control the elements of the earth for the good of crops, but can be used to create great famines; used as a portal to travel, however if in the wrong hands no hand will be safe or be able to keep out the evils of the land. We must retain these items, and leave the shores of Middle Earth with the items traveling with us on the high seas to the east." Elrond walked over to Daeloth and looked deeply into her eyes, and began talking to her in his mind. "This will not be an easy task, and the journal is filled with perils. Trust in your instincts and don't give weigh to your emotions. Stay unified in the Fellowship, and all will be assured."

Daeloth smiled and kissed his cheek. Elrond embraced her and handed her the map. "It is your turn now. Let the grace of the Elves protect you my grand-daughter. Stay close to the Fellowship, and trust in their council. They will not lead you astray."

"I will," she said.

"Go now, and make ready your journey."

1112111212.content:
Daeloth made her way to what the Halflings called the Great Room, for it was the greatest room of all of Rivendell. There a feast was being partaken in honour of all the counsels chosen to find the lost items of the Rivendell, Lothlorien, and of the Eldamar. All had their own special blessings given to them by the Half-Elven beloved Elbereth, or to the Halflings, Valimar. Though the tools were made during the better peaceful days of old, in a time where dwarfs and elves mingled together in great fellowship, they had now been turned to cause much sorrow across Middle Earth; especially in Osgiliath, and in the lands of the mighty horse lords of the Riddermark.

Both Osgiliath and Rohan had been plagued with famine and with the trials and tribulations caused by the Orcs, that led up to the Final Great War for the One Ring; which led, almost, to the total destruction of Rohan's respected Helm's Deep, and to great peril and destruction of Minas Anor, also known as Minas Tirith in the days of the Great Kings. The people were physically and emotionally famished. They needed time to heal from the loss of their loved ones, for over one third of the Riddermark Marshals were destroyed; King Théoden, Lord of the Mark, also fell among the bravest of Rohan leaving his nephew, Eomer, Lord of the Riddermark, and King. Peace had swept across the land, for none had known, save the Lords and Lady of the Elves, that these tools of power lay at rest in Middle Earth. This is why Lord Elrond called counsel once more, to keep this burned secret among the peoples of Middle Earth, and to find the items as quickly as possible.

Arwen came up to Daeloth and led her to the table where the Fellowship was feasting. With them sat two other individuals of whom she did not know, for she had seen little of those who lived beyond Rivendell and Fangorn Forest. Daeloth stood before the group as Arwen introduced her adopted daughter to them. "Daeloth, adopted daughter of Aragorn, son of Arathorn, and Arwen Evenstar, daughter of Lord Elrond; meet your new fellowship and family that will lead you through great fears and foes lingering in Middle Earth. Here sits Gimli, son of Gloin, Legoles you know, as well as our beloved Hobbits: Merry, Pippin, Sam, and Frodo. There sits also our allies, and kindred spirits of the Mark, King Eomer, and Lady Eowyn. Gandalf, whom you love is not here, but nigh on the mount. For he has many things, in which to meditate on this night, but will surely join us afterward. Sit now, and make merry with us."

Daeloth bowed and took her seat between Arwen and Eowyn. She and Eowyn began to talk as if they were childhood girlfriends, for they had many of things that were common among them. Eowyn was just a few years older than Daeloth, and also lost her mother as an infant. She did, however have the comfort of her father, yet could not remember him, for he was in constant war to keep the Riddermark free from the terrene of the Orci. She had wanted to make voice with Lord Eomer, but he seemed pre-occupied with the little ones and with his Marshals coming to and fro with counsel of his peoples. She could not help but notice the light that flickered in his hazel-green eyes. Even though his face was smart, his eyes showed great love for his people and his friends. Daeloth hoped that one day she could talk with him and perhaps become a friend to the great Lord of Rohan.

After supper, the Hobbits; Merry and Pippin, jumped up on the long feasting table and began to entertain the folk of the fellowship and the Elves. Even dear old Bilbo got up and sang a song, he had just written for the occasion earlier that day!

Tired and full, Daeloth stood up from the feast. "Please do not get up," she told the men, who were starting to stand in respect for the lady. "I shall retire for the evening. It was wonderful to meet you good dear folk, and I look forward to your counsel and companionship on our journey together. I shall see you in the morrow." She the turned to her mother and kissed her delicate hand and bid her good night, in which was returned by Arwen.

"Let me walk you, my Lady. For I too am exhausted from the journey and of the merriment of the evening," said Eomer as he stood from his seat. He then bowed,” I bid you all a good night, and ask your pardon for my leaving the feast so soon. My Lord Aragorn and Lady Arwen," he bowed again, in which Aragorn stood and nodded in return. Eomer then took Daeloth's hand and placed it upon his arm and led her out of the Great hall.

Eomer led her up many steps and past many talan before he had reached her room. Without a word the entire way up, he then turned to her and nodded his head as he prepared to leave. "My Lord, must you go?" she heard herself ask. Eomer turned, at which she again had seen the sparkle in his eyes.

"Do you bid me to leave or may I have the treasure of speaking with the grand-daughter of the Mighty Lord Elrond?" he smiled.

"Do not tease me, my Lord. For I love my grand-father dearly!" Daeloth replied.

Eomer took her hands into his. "I did not wish to offend, my lady. But I have long wanted to know your thoughts since I first saw you join us in the Great Hall. I regret my evening was filled with business, and I could not enjoy your company 'til now. But it is late, and if you prefer, I can call upon you in the morning, at the wakening of the sparrow?"

11121112121.content:
Daeloth awoke to the sound of gentle breathing by her bed. In one fluid motion she pulled her dagger from beneath her pillow and threw it at her attacker. She heard him dodge and the blade clatter uselessly to the floor. She jumped out of bed, and rushed him trying to strike him with her fist. He grabbed her arm and pulled it above her head, then snagged her waist with his other arm. Holding her thus, he dipped her and pressed a kiss to her mouth. Daeloth's eyes finally adjusted to the strange half-light which was filtering through her room and she recognized....

"Legolas??"

"Good morning my dear." Legolas smiled mischievously.

"What are you doing here? And why are you kissing me?" Daeloth's temper flared and she stomped on Legolas' instep, then elbowed him in the face, effectively freeing herself from his hold. She walked over to her bureau, pulled out a dressing gown, put it on and began braiding her long auburn hair.

"Well?" She asked again, as she finished braiding two sections of her hair, one on either side of her face, and looped them around her head, leaving the rest cascading like a waterfall down to the middle of her back. She turned impatiently to Legolas and discovered he was gone. She turned in confusion to her bed and saw that there was somebody lying it.

Assuming Legolas was playing a trick on her, she walked over to it and pulled the covers back. "Really Lego-" Daeloth stopped and screamed as she saw that Boromir's body was lying in her bed, covered with dozens of wounds and crawling with larva. Boromir opened his eyes, looked at her and stood up. Daeloth stood frozen in awe-struck horror as he moved toward her, placed his arms around her and leaned in to kiss her.

Daeloth felt tears fall from her eyes as she whimpered, "No. Please don't."

Suddenly the corpse of Boromir was replaced and the Boromir that she remembered was standing in front of her. He had his hand raised in a farewell wave and the smile on his face was the one he had given only to her.

"Farewell my love." He whispered softly, and then faded slowly away.

"Boromir! BOROMIR!" Daeloth screamed, sobbing.

Someone wrapped their arms around her and soothed, "Shhhh Daeloth. It's only a dream. Hush dear one. You're safe."

Daeloth turned and saw Eomer standing behind her. His eyes captured her as they had at dinner and she heard the whisper of Boromir's voice in her mind~ He will give you strength and grow to love you as you will one day love him. Choose him.

As his voice faded from her mind, Daeloth awoke.

She was wrapped tightly in a blanket and someone's arms, being gently rocked back and forth as someone softly sang an elven lullaby to her. It took her a moment to recognize the voice of her father and the arms of her mother. She relaxed and and the rocking and singing stopped. A candle was lit and by it's light she could see the worried faces of Arwen, Aragorn and Elrond looking down at her.

"How are you feeling dear heart?" Her father asked.

"I'm sorry to have worried all of you." Daeloth murmured softly.

Arwen hugged her a little tighter and said, "We love you Daeloth. You needn't apologize." She looked at her adopted daughter and tucked a few stray hairs behind her ears. "It's been years since you have had a vision. What was this one about?"

Daeloth looked at her grandfather. His eyes lit with understanding. "So it has begun."

Arwen and Aragorn looked from Daeloth to Elrond. "What has begun?" Aragorn asked.

Elrond turned to the window. "I had no wish to tell you this Aragorn, but Daeloth must accompany you. Some of the items you seek can not be found except by those in the other realm. Boromir's love for Daeloth keeps him connected to Middle Earth and it is that connection you will need to use to find some of the objects you seek." Elrond faced his family again. "This is the only way for Boromir's spirit to find peace. If you do not seek his help while completing this task, or seek his help and fail, Boromir will be doomed to dwell forever between this realm and the next."

"So the longer it takes us to find the objects, the more time I have with Boromir." Daeloth said slowly, hope rising in her heart.

Arwen carefully killed this destructive hope."No good can come of keeping him in limbo, dearest. You will not find a way to raise him from the dead, and the time you will spend with him will be in your dreams. You risk separating your body and your consciousness and being doomed forever yourself."

"Your mother is right, Daeloth. Besides, the longer he is trapped in limbo, the less his grasp of either realm will be. After awhile, he will be of no use to you and you will not be able to redeem him." Elrond added.

Daeloth's head and heart were spinning with everything she had just learned. Visions of Boromir and their time together kept flying through her mind, interrupted more and more frequently by the look in Eomer's eyes as they had said good night.

Arwen sensed her daughter's confusion and motioned for Aragorn and her father to leave. They both gave Daeloth a hug before they left and Aragorn kissed her on the forehead.

"Sleep well dear heart." He murmured.

Alone at last, Arwen faced her daughter. "Tell me of the one who has captured your heart."

Daeloth raised startled eyes to Arwen's face. "What?" She gasped.

Arwen tenderly stroked Daeloth's hair. "I raised you darling. I know you better than you know yourself. There is much confusion in you right now. And it has little to do with Boromir and much to do with a man you have recently met. Have you fallen for Legolas?"

"No." Daeloth admitted. "It is...Eomer."

"Ahhh. Gallent Eomer. I had wondered if he might catch your fancy."

"Mother!" Daeloth protested.

Arwen shushed her. "Daeloth, I know Boromir was your first love. But it was not meant to be. I am not saying it is your fault he died, so remove that silly notion from your head." Arwen waited until Daeloth nodded and then continued, "I think you were meant for another and perhaps it is time for you to stop mourning Boromir and find him."

"Wonderful timing Mother. I'm about to set out on a quest I might not return from, guided by the spirit of my dead love. Any man would love to come into a set of circumstances like that and sweep a girl off her feet." Daeloth frowned at her mother, increasingly frustrated with the way this night was going.

"Eomer understands war, Daeloth and I know that if he did not feel such an obligation to stay with his people, he would be joined the Fellowship. I also noticed the way he was watching you tonight when he was not distracted by messengers, and he watches you much the same way your father used to watch me."

"Used to, Mother?" Daeloth questioned.

Her mother smiled fondly in remembrance. "Yes used to. Before we pledged ourselves to each other, when he still thought I could never love one such as he. Eomer has the same look in his eyes when he gazes at you."

Unbidden Boromir's last words came to her mind. He will give you strength and grow to love you as you will one day love him. Choose him.

Daeloth bowed her head and said quietly, "But I still love Boromir." A single tear traced a path down her cheek, shining like a diamond in the candlelight.

Arwen gently placed her hand under Daeloth's chin and raised her eyes to meet her own. "Oh darling," She said. "You always will. He was your first love and no one can take his place in your heart. But there is room in your heart for another and I think Eomer is the one. Just give him a chance. That's all I ask."

Daeloth looked in to her mother's beautiful eyes and felt herself wavering on a tightrope. She was going to fall any second, but it was up to her which side she fell off of.

11121112122.content:
Daeloth bowed her head gracefully and apologized, "I regret, my lord that I must leave with the Fellowship on the morrow before the days first light. I tend to eat my morning meal as we make way to the Misty Mountains."

"I am sure before your task is finished we shall meet again, my lady." Eomer took Daeloth’s hand and kisses it gently as he exited her room and retired for the evening.

Daeloth took out the map that Elrond had given her and began to study it. As she unrolled the map, a thin piece of paper fell out of it. Daeloth thought this to be odd because she had watched Elrond roll the map, yet did not see him place anything inside.

On the paper were items written, in old Elfish tongue, ingredients to potions with numbers places on the left side of each. It was extremely had for her to translate, for she had not learned the old Elfish that well. She took out her journal and began to translate as much as she could without having to guess what the words meant. She then looked at the map and noticed something peculiar.

Beside meadows, mountains, forests, bodies of water and in desert areas were randomly placed numbers. Daeloth glanced back at the piece of paper that had fallen out of the map and put her finger on the map at the same time. She had come to the conclusion that the numbers on the map clearly had something to do with the items listed on the paper. She did not have much time left in the evening to investigate the similarities of the two, and continued to translate the paper.

It took her almost four hours before she had finished the task of translating the potions before she felt she had done her best. She went to her pack and stuffed the small journal into one of the outside flaps and shut it. She then went over to her belt and unsheathed her sword and two daggers Elrond had crafted specially for her years ago. The blades had become dull over the usage of the items throughout the many years she had owned them. She took out a stone from a pocked on her trousers and headed to the window sill. As she sat down she gave the stone a good lick with her tongue and began to sharpen her sword. Back and forth she glided the rock up and down the edge until she felt she could get the blade no sharper. She repeated the process two more times with her daggers.

After feeling competent that she had made her sword and daggers lethal weapons again, she went to her quiver and counted the arrows that lay inside. She only counted ten, which would not last if the Fellowship were to fall into an ambush. She went to her shrunk, which contained more sticks, already sharpened arrow heads, and Elfish styled golden feathers. She took the bundle of item over to the small rounded wooded table that was placed in the middle of her room and began to piece as many arrows as she could together. Before she could finish the task, her eyes became extremely heavy, and soon she fell fast asleep; feathers and arrow heads in hand.

**************************************************

"Daeloth, wake up," she heard a familiar voice say. Daeloth turned her head to see Samwise Gamgie standing next to her with all her things gathered up and tossed on the little hobbits back. "The Fellowship is to meet at the Seat of the Counsel before we take off. I tried convincing King Aragorn to let us all have a proper breakfast, so we could have full stomachs to head out if you get my meaning my lady. But, Aragorn insisted we leave before the rise of the blue birds."

You stomp away with your head held high. An elf thinks he can tell you of feelings? Magical powers, everlasting life, what do they know of reality? They are living in a dream world you tell yourself, not the real one.
You march back to the place where you are staying and happily find a fire lit in the grate. It is perfectly warm outside but the light from the fire is comforting...it might put you to sleep soon if you aren't careful.
You sit on the mahogany chair before the fire and pick up your sword. It has the carving of your favorite horse on it: Prelatara...meaning "Spotted Chariot" {(this isnt real guys, sorry made up a name}}
He was your only friend before, he was a true hunter..one who could feel the wind and face fear at the same. He was your comrade. Comrade. You miss the word. Everyone here is turning against you.

It's time to change that.
1112112121122121.title: Comraderie

You turn from Legolas and walk in the opposite direction. You hear him call out to you, but you turn a deaf ear to him. Suddenly, he runs past you and stops in front of you.

1112112121122122.title: A Challenge for Legolas

choices: Agree to let him escort you to your room
Struggle, and end up like a sack of potatoes
11121121211222.content: You reach out to slap Legolas, but he sees it coming, and reaches up to grab your wrist. You try to strike with your other hand, but again, he anticipates. 11121121211222.title: Lighten up a Little

111211212112221.content:

1112112121122211.content:

1112112121122211.title: Drifting

11121121211222112.content:
Aragorn turns to Legolas. "The evil is growing, Elrond informed me," he says. "If the Fellowship is to leave it must be soon." A thrill of excitement courses down your spine---the trip will start!

"Go find everyone," Aragorn continues, speaking not just to his elfin companion but also to you. He nods to both of you, and walks off.

"I know where Frodo went off to," you tell Legolas. "I will find him." You feel a bit uncomfortable being alone with Legolas, though you're not exactly sure why. Maybe it's something about his eyes, or that half-smile, or....you shake your head to rid them of the traitorous thoughts. Falling in love with an elf is considered one of the more stupid things to do when you're human, you remind yourself sternly. And anyway--love?? where did that come from?

You manage a nod in Legalos' general direction and turn away. You actually don't know where the little hobbit went off to, but you have a pretty good guess---with Gandalf, where he seems to spend most of his time.
11121121211222112.title: Stay and talk with them

choices: Go to your room (this would be the right thing to do)
Sneak away to see where everyone else is
1112112121122212.content:
You stick your nose into the air slightly higher.
"I'm not sure I know what you mean," you say, looking away slightly.
Legolas laughs and shakes his head.
"Then I was wrong, you ARE in need of protection. But remember this, when your stubborness and pride starts to hurt others besides yourself, then it becomes more than a trait. It becomes a threat."
He walks faster, leading up hill and down a stone pathway to your room, leaving you at the door.

You watch him walk quietly away.
1112112121122212.title: Letting Go

11121121211222121.content:
You shut the door behind you, and shed your weapons. Noticing a wash basin on a dresser, you walk to it and splash warm water on your face. Your face still wet, you reach out to try to find a towel. Your hand finds it and you dry your face. As you turn around, you see that you are not alone. Gandalf sits in a chair in the corner. You are surprised to see him in your room, but you try hard to show no reaction. He motions toward the chair next to him. You obey, and sit beside him, and wait. After what seems like forever, he speaks.
"Your heart is in great turmoil, Daeloth. You must overcome this battle before you can aide in the greater battle to come."
You open your mouth to speak, but he holds up his hand, and looks into your eyes.
"Perhaps this will be the hardest battle you will ever be forced to fight, but until you do, the new fellowship must remain here."
You lower your head, as he rises to leave.
"You have but two choices. Admit your true feelings to yourself, and deal with them. Or, rid yourself of them forever, and move on."
With that, he is gone. You raise your head and stare tear-eyed out the window. Do you...
11121121211222121.title: To Look Inside Yourself

111211212112221212.content:
Slowy you fix your gaze to the horizon and let your mind fade. You presently feel the stinging of your old scars and bite your lip to keep from crying out.

You had to forget, forget the pain, forget the fear, forget the memories. And you knew the only way to do that was to face them.
111211212112221212.title: Facing your fears

1112112121122212121.content:
You close your eyes and take in a deep breath, allowing all the hatred, anger, fear, everything that you knew stopped you and the other from continuing your quest engulf you.

The pain surging through your body sends you to your knees on the floor. But you dont open your eyes, you remain focused on that pain, on your past horrors and scars.

That was the only way you could be set free.

Your mind revisists the torture chambers and you hear your own screams of pain echoing through your ears, you can smell the blood, the fire, the stench of orc, you can see the darkness sweeping through, you can taste Sauron's cruelty.

Furiously you stand up and turn to see...

Legolas grunts but only swings you over his shoulder. "What?" You cry out angrily. "Legolas put me down!" You command trying to get into a position where you can strike his neck.

He must have anticiotaied your plan because he had you in a position where you couldnt.

"Legolas," You growl in a low tone. He was going too far.

111211212121.title: Lord Aragorn

watch and wait to see where he's going
1112112121212.content:
You nod and sit down next to him, careful not to expose the long, ugly scar on your left arm.

"I've heard your name long ago," Aragorn started looking at you.

You look at him curiously.

"Were you not sent by Gandalf to help Frodo and Sam during the war with Sauron?"

You blink and look at the ground on which you sat.

That had been your quest, you hadnt known Gandalf for long but he had asked it of you and you accepted.

But it all turned out wrong, you were captured and totured senseless by the orcs. Hence your hatred towards them, though you hardly ever showed your anger in fear you would cuase more harm to yourself than your life already had.
