You see Legolas coming up and you shake your head, wanting to rid yourself forever of those painful memories.

You..
1112112121212.title: Failed Quest

11121121212121.content:
"Hello, Legolas," you call out. "Looking for a fight with me again? I already told you, I shall not fight you for fear of injuring you."

"Ah, no fear there," he answers. "I wouldn't dream of losing to you."

For some reason, that rubs you the wrong way. "You may not dream of it, but the impossible does happen."

Aragorn laughs, reminding you why you sat down in the first place. "She speaks the truth, my friend." Wincing, he got off the ground and extinguished his pipe. "Haven't we been an example of that?" With a small grin, Legolas admits this is true. "So, Daeloth," Aragorn continues, "Are you ready for what lies ahead?" You tense, angry again, but you catch no mockery in his words...just an honest question.

"Ready for anything, my lord," you answer, still sprawled on the ground. "Your wish is my command."
11121121212121.title: You Need Legolas!!!

111211212121212.content:
Aragorn nods at you, clearly pleased with your answer. Just then running feet breaks in, and the three of you whirl around, ready for anything. But it is only Frodo. "Ah, Frodo, so nice of you to join us," greets Legolas.

But the little hobbit looks anything but pleased. "Elrond needs us. All of us, right away. He says it concerns our quest and it's very important!"

Soon, all nine of the Fellowship---Frodo, Pippin Merrie and Sam the hobbits; Gandalf; Nimli the dwarf; Legolas; Aragorn; and you, the newest addition---are gathered in a secret room. Elrond sits at the head of a great table, looking very grave. He motions for all of you to sit down. Everyone obeys, with four on each side and Aragorn sitting across from Elrond. You find yourself in between Pippin and Galdalf.

Elrond raps on the table for silence. "I thank you all for coming so quickly. I will get right to the point: a new evil is growing. Middle Earth is depending on you, the Fellowship, to find the source of this evil...and stop it." He pauses and seems to look each of you straight in the eyes. "We have reports of Orcs roaming in the Forgotten Forest." On your left, you feel Pippin stiffen, and on your right, Gandalf shifts uneasily. You yourself grip the edge of the table so hard, your knuckles turn white.

"But," continues Elrond, "from the Mines of Moria come other strange reports. Both are dangerous. Which one will you go to?"

Aragorn glances around the table, letting his gaze linger on each member of the Fellowship. "We will talk it over, Elrond. Please excuse us for a few moments." The elf nods and leaves the room.

The young king stands and asks simply, "What does the Fellowship choose?"
111211212121212.title: Important Choices

choices: Listen to the voice, and stay silent
1112112121212121.content:
The Fellowship all agree to go to the Forgotten Forest, and Aragorn informs Elrond. The very next day, the journey begins.

For about a day and a half, all of you ride hard. During this time you learn as much as you can about the Forgotten Forest. You find that it is a dark place, full of unknown creatures. 'Some not so unknown,' you think bitterly of the Orcs. You finger your thin blades---they are strapped in an X across your back, hidden by your cloak. To draw them, you cross your arms over your chest and put one hand on each shoulder...and on each blade. Then you whip them out, much to the surprise of your unfortunate victim! But your twin blades aren't all of your weapons: you also have, hanging on your belt, some daggers which you can throw with deadly accuracy.

It's night now...the evening of your second day on the trail. Nimli and Sam are trying to make a fire but are having little success. Frodo is frowning---he disagrees that we should stop, but everyone is tired and needs to rest. But you can't sleep. After tossing and turning for a while, you kick off your blanket in disgust. Practice, you decide, will help. So you grab your daggers and head to a little grove of trees about 30 yards away from the camp. It's close enough that you can see the sight, yet far enough that you won't disturb the others.

Almost an hour passes as you practice throwing your daggers. You pick different trees and try to hit a particular spot: a leaf, a branch, a crack, and once, a large bug. You are so absorbed in this that you fail to stay on your guard. To your credit there are no snapping twigs, rustling leaves, or anyhting else to warn you.

Suddenly an unseen assailant grabs you around the waist, pinning your arms to your sides. You struggle in vain and open your mouth to scream. A voice whispers, "Be quiet", and you...
1112112121212121.title: The Forgotten Forest

choices: You distract the Orcs, and Legolas warns the camp
11121121212121212.content:
Quickly, you clamp your mouth shut before any sound escapes. Whatever it is, it must have a weapon pointed at you. One dagger still hangs from your belt, and you strain to reach it. Your fingertips just brush the handle...got it! Holding the weapon firmly in your hand, you arch your back to give yourself more room. Whoever is holding you is strong but not overpoweringly so. It chuckles softly, and you falter, because the sound is quite familiar. Having just begun the strike with the dagger, your hand slips, and the blade just nicks the attacker's hand.

"Ow! Daeloth! So this is what happens when someone attacks you from behind..." You break free from his grasp and whirl around, although you already know who it is. A tall, blond elf holds his scratched hand to his eyes, studying it. With a few whispered words, the wound closes up and disappears. That taken care of, Legolas grins boyishly at you. "Surprise?"

You are definitley not amused. "Ha ha, very funny. I could have killed you!"

Legolas rolls his eyes. "You only wish, my Lómelith," he snorts, using the nickname he gave you.

Now it's you who rolls your eyes. "What are you doing out here anyway?" you ask, changing the subject.

"I had the first watch, and when you ran off, I figured you could take care of yourself. But it's been a long time, and I feared you had lost your way." Angrily, you start to reply to that, but you catch the glint in his eye and know he is only teasing. Instead you bend down and pick up the dropped dagger. When you straighten up, you find that Legolas has retrieved your two other ones from the trees at which you threw them. You accept them with a murmured word of thanks. "I suppose we'd better return," you remark.

"Yes, my watch is going to be over soon," Legolas answers. The two of you make your way out of the trees, quietly chatting about the journey. Then Legolas holds up a hand and puts a finger to his lips. You immediately stop talking and peer around him to see what's wrong.

What you see makes you gasp. A band of Orcs is moving towards the camp! Legolas motions to them, and then to the camp. His meaning is clear: one of you will distract the Orcs and the other will warn the camp. Who will do what?
11121121212121212.title: Listen to the Voice

111211212121212121.content:
Whipping out your concealed blades, you gesture towards the Orcs, letting Legolas know that you'll take care of them. He hesitates, looking unsure; but the stubborn expression on your face convinces him that you won't be changing your mind any time soon. He whispers "Hislali"---Elvish for "good luck". Then he is gone, running to warn the Fellowship.

As for you, you're running too, but in a different direction. When you get near enough to the band, you count and get a rough estimate of about seventy-five. Just enough for this little mission to be classified as "suicide". You hold your twin blades firmly in your hands, and they reassure you a bit. Though they make look thin and flimsy, actually they were forged to be unbreakable---within reason, of course. But they are still much stronger than any battle sword Aragorn will ever posess. And as for your daggers: before you left, Elrond placed a spell on them. No matter how far you throw them, the whispered word of "murisl" will send them right back into their sheaths.

The Orcs are set on one thing---the camp---so they don't pay any attention to you. Well, you are moving almost in complete silence through the tall grass. Maybe they don't even know you're here, you hope. But the objective of your mission is not to stay hidden. It's to distract the Orcs until the Fellowship comes to your aid. Or leaves to safety. Either one works.

You are ahead of the band now, but not by much. Just ahead of you are some cliffs, with a semi-narrow entrance in between them. You pause...they give you an idea. If you are quick, you can climb up the cliff and cause an avalanche that will make the entrance even smaller and maybe block it off completely. But if you don't do it fast enough, the Orcs could get through and yu would be on the cliffs, powerless to stop them.

Only seconds remain for you to make your decision. Choose quickly!
111211212121212121.title: You distract the Orcs

1112112121212121211.content:
You decide that the result of making an avalanche outweighs the risk. Nimble as a mouse, you scurry up the cliffs. Your destination is a large boulder, which sits precariously on a ledge that's a little less than halfway up the slope. Once you reach it, you waste no time in getting behind it and firmly planting your feet. A hard shove is all it takes to get it moving, and it tumbles wildly down the cliff. As you had hoped, it creates a rockslide of other stones and debris. Some Orcs have already made it through the entrance, but they are the first of few. Your makeshift avalanche fills nearly all of the gap, and the crack that's left is barely big enough for two or three Orcs to squeeze in at at a time---and when they do, you will be waiting for them.

But first you must take care of the five that already made it through. Placing your swords down, you grab your daggers and throw them in rapid succession. Two Orcs are down and your daggers are gone. "Murisl!" you yell, and just like that, the three daggers are back in their sheaths. "What do you know...it works!" Aided by Elrond's spell, you finish off the rest of the Orcs.

Daggers, though, will not defeat the army. It's time to put your sword-skills to the test. Half-jumping, half-sliding, you make it down the cliff just as two Orcs stumble through the crack. "Hello," you greet them. With a spin and two well-placed thrusts, they fall dead to the ground. "Goodbye." Three more squeeze through, but you dispose of them too. "Daeloth, this is the best idea you've had in a while," you congratulate yourself. Instead of fighting the entire Orc army, you get to take on a few on a time. True, this is still no easy feat; but two or three is better than seventy-five.

A shout makes you look up. Doing so causes you to lose your concentration, and the Orc you were fighting trips you up. He smashes his ax at you, but you roll to the side and it thuds into the earth. He yanks it up and raises it again---only to stop as an odd look comes over his face. Dropping the ax, he steps back and collapses, an arrow embedded in his chest. Legolas is back, with the Fellowship!
1112112121212121211.title: Avalanche!!!!

11121121212121212111.content:
Legolas shouts again, and you raise your arm in thanks. Now it's back to killing Orcs, but this time, you have help. You see Nimli swinging his battle-ax and Aragorn mowing down Orcs with ease. Then you catch a glimpse of Frodo, who is fighting an Orc that's twice his size. You decide to help him out, and with a flick of your wrist, send a dagger spinning into the Orc's back. He grunts in surprise and Frodo cuts him down.

"Thanks, Daeloth," he calls. You nod back at him, then pause. Frodo's sword is glowing blue---so brightly that it illimunates the battle place. You know about the whole "glow when evil is around" thing, but this is very, very bright.

"What does it mean?" you ask, gesturing to his blade. The hobbit frowns and shrugs uneasily. Perhaps it means nothing. The stream of Orcs that has been steadily flowing through the crack has slowed considerably. You dare to hope that the battle is almost over!
11121121212121212111.title: The Fellowship Helps You

111211212121212121111.content:
Eager to finish the battle, Aragorn runs to the crack and starts thrusting his sword, stabbing any Orcs who are still trying to get through. You join him, and together you work to kill the Orcs. He looks over at you and laughs in delight, and you nod in response.

Then something starts to happen. The Orcs stop coming, but your victory is short-lived. A rumbling starts---softly at first, but growing ominously louder. Without warning, your makeshift wall explodes, throwing Aragorn backwards though you manage to hang on. "What's happening?" you scream to no one in particular. Your words die in your throat, though, when you see what is behind the wall.

At first, all you see is the group of Orcs, huddling around something. But as they stop aside, they reveal who is responsible for shattering the wall. A tall man, clothed in a simple black robe, glides out. He holds a staff that's like Gandalf's...a wizard! A dark wizard, to be more exact. You turn to run, but he fixes his gaze on you, and you find that moving is impossible. With a grim smile, he mutters something and waves his staff---and suddenly you are flying through the air, straight towards the Orcs.

You land hard, and your wind is knocked out. As you lie there gasping, a huge hand grabs your hair, yanking your body upright. It's the lead Orc, and he doesn't look friendly. He growls at you, then at the dark wizard, who simply inclines his head. The Orc bares his teeth in a horrible smile, and you know you have been sentenced to die.

Effortlessly, the Orc hoists you off the ground, still holding you by your hair. The pain brings tears to your eyes but you know it's nothing compared to what you'll probably be enduring in a few moments. He carries you over to one of the scattered trees that dot the field. Before you have time to wonder why, he shoves you against the unyielding bark and places his hand around your throat. You know very well that he could simply snap your neck, but Orcs enjoy seeing their victims suffer.

Your world is going black at the edges. "No..." you choke out, but the Orc just growls with pleasure. This is it, you realize, and a wave of sadness sweeps over you. I'm sorry, Aragorn; and Legolas...please forgive me for all I've done, you plead silently.

Your eyes flutter close.
111211212121212121111.title: The Fight Continues

choices: In the Forest, with the Fellowship
1112112121212121211111.content:
Your breath is gone, and you're slipping into unconsciousness. But suddenly the pressure around your neck disappears, and you sink to the ground, barely awake. You manage to open your eyes a slit, and you see the Orc grappling hand-to-hand with someone...Aragorn! Mustering all your strength, you try to sit up, but it's no use---you're still too weak to do anything but watch. So that's why you can do nothing, not even shout a warning, as another Orc slips up behind Aragorn.

You shouldn't have worried. The second Orc goes down with an arrow between his shoulder blades. "Thanks, Legolas," you breath, quieter than a butterfly's wingbeat. Aragorn swings his sword and takes care of the Orc that tried to kill you. Then he whirls around, and when he sees you, his face softens.

"Daeloth," he gasps. "Are you..."

"Well, I'm not dead, if that's what you mean," you quip softly. "But...pretty close." You confirm this last statement with a racking cough that almost knocks you out again.

From the corner of your eye, you see flashes of light, and raise your eyebrows quizzically. Aragorn catches it and answers solemnly, "Gandalf is fighting with the---other---wizard." Your eyes widen, and you motion weakly in the direction of the wizards, hoping he'll understand. He does, and tells you, "But I couldn't let you die." You gaze up at him in surprise, and he adds quickly, "...Legolas would kill me."

Ignoring that last statement, you start to speak. "You have...to...go," you mutter brokenly.

With a worried look in his eyes, Aragorn asks, "But can you walk?" You nod, but actually you doubt it. You know you have to try, though---Aragorn won't leave you here. So you take a deep breath and, with Aragorn's help, find yourself standing. You flash him a triumphant look...and crumple to the ground, unconscious. When you wake up, you're:
1112112121212121211111.title: NOT the end

11121121212121212111111.content:
A hobbit face, leaning over yours, is the first thing you see when you finally awaken. "Pippin?" you ask groggily. "Is that you?...ow," you add, as your body reminds you why you were asleep. Almost every part of you aches, or is bleeding, or just plain hurts.

Pippin jumps back in surprise. Then his face breaks out into a grin. "Hey!" he yells. "Daeloth's alive! She's---" A hand clamps over his mouth, cutting off the rest of whatever he was about to say.

"Silence, Peregrine Took," warns Gandalf, for it was his hand that silenced the loudmouth. "There are many creatures in this forest that would not think twice about having you for a snack." He releases the hobbit, who glances around nervously. That done with, the old wizard turns his attention to you. "Daeloth. Back from the dead, are we?"

"Not quite," you answer wryly. "Where are we?"

"In the Forgotten Forest, damn this place," answers Nimli, coming up beside Gandalf. "Not my first choice but it's better than being torn apart by Orcs. In fact, I'd say just about anything is better than being torn apart by Orcs."

"Orcs!" you gasp. How could you have forgotten? "Is everyone all right?" you ask. "And you, Gandalf, fighting the wizard! How did you defeat him? And how did I get here if I was unconcious the whole time?" Questions bubble out of you faster than an avalanche. Oh, right, the avalanche!

"Slow down," laughs Gandalf. Then his tone turns serious. "To answer your first question...well, everyone who's here is all right."

His words cause you to go cold. Someone didn't make it. You force yourself to sit up and have a look around the campsite. Merrie, Pippin, Nimli, Gandalf, and you are here. Legolas, Aragorn, Sam and Frodo are missing. "No!" you whisper, horrorstruck. "What has happend to them? Four of the Fellowship are gone..." you close your eyes in despair.

"What's that? Four? Oh, no, Daeloth; just two." You open your eyes and peer quizzically at Gandalf. "Frodo and Sam made it here with us, but they disappeared, lost in the forest. It is a very easy thing to do, mark my words," he tells you gravely. You start to ask a question, but Gandalf anticipates it and shushes you. "Legolas and Aragorn are merely out searching for them." You can't help but feel relieved at this, though the sense is quickly followed by regret and worry for the two missing hobbits.

"Well, speak of the devil now!" cuts in Nimli, motioning towards a figure making his way into the camp. It's...
11121121212121212111111.title: In the Forest, with the Fellowship

111211212121212121111111.content:
The figure is Aragorn. He walks as one whose troubles are too great, and the burden he carries too heavy, for one of his age and stature. When he sees you awake and sitting up, though, some of the worry melts off of his face. "Good afternoon, Daeloth. I thought you would quit on us and leave this world, even as I had just saved your life." He says it lightly, but you catch an undertone of huge relief.

"You won't be getting rid of me that easily, I'm afraid, my lord," you answer in a teasing tone. Aragorn answers with a tired grin, which fades as his eyes rove around the campsite.

"Legolas has not returned yet?" he asks, a note of concern entering his voice. "Without warning, he ran off and away from my side, just as we were drawing near to the camp. At the time I assumed he was simply trying to get back here faster"---for some reason, Aragorn's eyes fix on you---"but I see that was not the case." A grim looks steals over his face. "There are many strange things that are said to roam these woods," he murmurs, lost in thought. "I hope..." Aragorn does not finish his last sentence, choosing instead to let it trail off into the fading light. A somber quietness descends over what remains of the Fellowship.

Supper that night is cold and silent. Cold because Aragorn forbids a fire. Silent because the three missing members of the band have not returned. You pick miserably at your food, part of the reason being that you're not sure it's edible. But the main reason why you cannot eat is because you are sick at heart. One thing in particular that haunts you the most? The fact that what may have been your last moments ever with Legolas were spent in unconciousness. Yes, you do feel something for him, deep in a hidden place inside yourself---a place that you haven't brought to light in a very long time. But now that you have admitted your feelings to yourself, it may be too late, and you will never have had the chance to open up your heart. You know that if Legolas does not return, you will shrink those feelings of love inside of yourself, back to the dark hidden place...and you may never bring it out again.

As it grows darker, you volunteer for first watch. Anything's better than lying on your sleeping roll as these confusing thoughts and more battle in youe head. When you head up to your post...Merrie taps you and, when you turn around, wordlessly hands you your twin blades. "Thank you," you murmur, overcome by such a thoughtful gesture. The hobbit smiles and scurries away. So you stand atop two boulders which were deemed the 'lookout' post and begin your watch. Your nerves are so frayed, every little noise has you on your toes, ready for a fight.

The night goes on, and before you know it, your watch is over. Nimli relieves you, but as you walk away, you hear it----footsteps. You turn silently to Nimli, who grips his ax, letting you know that he head it too. Then, out of the shadows, steps...
111211212121212121111111.title: Aragorn Returns

choices: You continue on your rant and eventually wind down.
1112112121212121211111111.content:
"Legolas?!" you and Nimli gasp in disbelief, at the exact same time. The tall blond elf raises his head and gives you both a dazzling smile.

"Yes, it is I," he whispers back. "Thank you for not giving up on me. I apoligize if I caused you any trouble..."

"Any TROUBLE?" you whisper as loudly as you dare, putting in all of the emotions you felt and are feeling now: rage, helplessness, disbelief and, buried somewhere under those three, relief. But you don't let him hear the last one in your voice. "Oh, no, none at all! The fact that you ran off from Aragorn's side, with no good reason, into this unknown jungle where the most likely outcome of being lost is death---we were perfectly fine with that! None of us worried at all!" By now you are hissing the words through your teeth, making them sound like a threat. Legolas takes a step back, raising his hands in surrender, all while keeping that infuriating smile. This just makes you angrier!
1112112121212121211111111.title: Legolas Is Back

11121121212121212111111111.content:
"So you think this is funny?!" you growl at him. "Yes, we were all laughing when Aragorn came back and told us that you just left him, right in the middle of the Forest. You idiot. Whatever in Middle Earth possessed you to do that?" He starts to speak, but you cut him off, not wanting to hear any stupid excuses. "Oh, I suppose a tree-nymph came out of her tree and told you to follow her. Or did you see an Orc in the shadows and tried to get away from it? I see by the look on your face that you think these things would never happen to you. But I'm sure your excuse will be so much better." You pause for a breath of air, and Legolas quietly breaks in.

"Daeloth, Nimli, I understand that I caused you---and the Fellowship---much worry when I left." You roll your eyes, and he ignores you. "But believe it or not, I did have a good reason for leaving Aragorn's side. What happened after that was poor judgement on my part, and yet Daeloth, you would not hesitate if someone was in trouble, would you?"

"In trouble?" You blink, puzzled. "Well, no; if someone needed my help, I would surely give it freely."

"Then by your standards, my reason is a solid one. As Aragorn and I were heading back here, I saw an Orc attacking something. My ears caught, on the wind, a cry for help. I grabbed my weapon and raced off, not even thinking of what I was doing. I just knew that someone who was unaccustomed to fighting Orcs was in trouble, and I was there to help them."

For a few moments, both you and Nimli are silent, trying to figure out if he's telling the truth. "Who is this person that you saved, then?" asks Nimli cautiously.
11121121212121212111111111.title: You continue on your rant and eventually wind d...

111211212121212121111111111.content:
"A child of the Forest," Legolas answers simply.

"What? No one lives in this place. You are out of your mind!" Nimli tells him. "Psh. A child, indeed!"

"No, no, that is where you are wrong," Legolas counters. "People do live here! A race of human-like beings who survive and even thrive in the Forest. They are called the..." he frowns as he tries to remember. "The Dennali. 'Dennali' literally does mean 'child of the Forest' in Elvish, so obviously they are a learned people. Or perhaps they are of elven descent."

"Then who is this child?" you break in, tired of this. "Or, rather, where?"

"Why, she's---" Legolas turns around and does a double-take. "Where'd she go?" He begins looking in the thick shrubbery surrounding the clearing. "Come out," he calls softly. "They are friends of mine." There is a slight rustling, but nothing emerges.

"Legolas," you start, "are you perhaps feeling all right? Did you hit your head on a branch, or...anything like that?" For truly he is starting to worry you, what with his ramblings of a "Forest-child".

"I'm not leaving. It's true," he says stubbornly, but your well-trained eye catches a glimpse of the weariness on his face. He starts to sway back and forth on his feet.

"You are going to fall down dead, and then you will wish you came with me," you tell him. Then you pull out your daggers with a smile to let him know that you are only joking. "Are my convincing words enough, or do I have to bring you back with brute force? Come, Prince of the Elves, you are so tired that you have been hallucinating." He shakes his head at this, but shrugs to let you know that he will come with you.

"I come not of mine own free will, warrior," Legolas says, with a hint of mirth in his voice. "But your daggers are enough to make me come."

Then all of a sudden, something explodes out of the brush---right onto you! It wraps its arms around you, and you catch sight of a blade gleaming in the darkness. Instinct takes over, and you duck and roll, trying to flip the thing off. Its hold loosens, and you take advantage of this be arching your back and slamming onto the ground repeatedly. As soon as you feel the hold slacken even more, you grab your dagger and spin over with the point of your blade pointed right at the thing's neck. Then you halt in shock.
111211212121212121111111111.title: A Forest-child

choices: Ask who the dark wizard is.
Ask where Sam and Frodo are.
1112112121212121211111111111.content:
Staring back up at you with wide, surprised eyes is...a young-looking girl! You take a step back and she springs to her feet, her breath coming in short blasts. She doesn't run off, though, allowing you to thoroughly examine her. At first glance she appeared to be young, maybe only ten or eleven, but now you see that she is in those middle years: the ones between childhood and young-adulthood. Her skin is not pale or even tan, but oddly streaked with shadows and dirt, which allows her to blend in with practically anything. When you look closer you realize that it is part of her natural coloring. Her ragged black hair is cropped close to her chin, and her eyes are darker than a shadowed cave at midnight.

Of what race is she? you wonder. As you study her further, it seems that she is part of every one. Her obvious look is human, and yet, she holds herself like royalty---or an elf. Her ears are even slightly pointed. But she is slim and small like a hobbit. It is also clear that she is 'one' with nature, like the dwarves.

Legolas quickly steps up. "Daeloth," he says quietly, "this is Mexle."

"M-ex-el." You try out the odd-sounding name.

"She is the Dennali that I rescued from the Orc." At this the girl comes alive and turns to Legolas. She starts chattering away in a queer tongue that, again, seems to be a mix of every language. You catch some words that obviously have Elvish, Human and Dwarvish roots; but not enough that you understand what she is saying. Legolas, at least, seems to understand her.

"Mexle says that you are a better fighter than you look," Legolas reports when the girl finishes.

You are unsure whether to be insulted or flattered. You finally decide on, "Um, can you tell her 'thank you'?...I think," you add under your breath.

The girl--Mexle---turns to you and speaks in a soft, musical voice that seems to have a gritty edge to it. The thing is, she speaks in plain Human. "You are quite welcome. This is good that you have the mind to know when you have been given a compliment."

"Oh, uh, not a problem," you answer in surprise.

"Enough of this," she answers shortly. "The prince has saved my life from one of the Orrulk that roams this wood. I am in his debt. Anything you wish to know, please ask, and I will answer it to the best of my abilities."
1112112121212121211111111111.title: Legolas didn't lie

choices: She agrees to send a guide.
She says that the rest of the Fellowship are not allowed to come.
11121121212121212111111111112.content:
You glance at Legolas, who looks back at you. Obviously he has no idea what he should ask this strange girl. But you know exactly what to say. "Two of our companions are missing. They are hobbits, and we know not of what befell them."

Mexle turns to stare at you. "The prince must ask," she says in a soft, rebuking voice, "for it was he that saved me." She makes these last few words sound accusing...as if you should have saved her.

Legolas looks at you and grins. Chastened, you motion for him to go ahead. He turns back to the Dennali girl and says simply, "My question was to be what Daeloth just asked. Please answer as though it was I who asked." Mexle gazes back at him, a little smile on her face. She seems to be drinking in this moment before she answers.

"Follow me, prince. You too, human and dwarf," she tells you and Nimli, a little more gruffly than how she said it to Legolas. "Let's be off."

"Wait a minute!" protests Nimli. "It's the dead of night, and we're supposed to go running off through this creepy forest with just a little girl as a guide?"

Mexle glares murderously at him and you, sensing a storm brewing, quickly step in. "Nimli, perhaps you can go and get Aragorn. Mexle, could you...I don't know...send a guide back here so that the rest of our companions may also follow us?"
11121121212121212111111111112.title: Ask where Sam and Frodo are.

111211212121212121111111111121.content:
"Yes," Mexle agrees tiredly. "I shall send a guide. You will not be lost to your friends. Now you, dwarf, go and tell them what is happening. Unless you wish to come with the prince and I?" She says it in a way that suggests she hopes he won't.

"And I," you remind her. No-o-o way are you going to let Legolas go off on his own---not so soon after you thought you had lost him forever. Besides, something about this girl has you feeling uncomfortable. Maybe it's the way she tries to make everyone feel insuperior to her; or the way she seems to look down on your skills; or...the fact she admires Legolas. It's more than just admiration, actually. She looks as though she fancies herself to be falling in love with him.
111211212121212121111111111121.title: A guide will come

1112112121212121211111111111211.content:
As you, Mexle, and Legolas walk through the thick woods, you carefully observe Mexle's actions towards Legolas. She is always trying to get next to him, to show him something of interest. Yes, it's safe for you to say that she finds herself attracted to the gracious elf. And who wouldn't be? He is the brightest thing in this dreary forest. A kind or funny word is always ready at his lips, and he poses no threat anyone; or so it seems. When he is fighting, he can still take anyone's breath away at how graceful and yet how strong he is. "Ha," you mutter under your breath as Mexle catches Legolas's arm to keep him from brushing up against a thorny bush. You know that however strongly Mexle wishes, they cannot be together. Although Legolas looks just a bit older than Mexle, he is in fact about a thousand years older and wiser.

You stop in surprise as something occurs to you. He is a thousand years older and wiser than you, too! So if it is impossible for Mexle to be with him...how is it possible for you to be with him? The only way for an elf and a human to live a happily married life is if the elf will give up his or her immortality. And what elf would do that? True, Aragorn and Eowyn are an example of this; but their love was greater than ever seen before. In addition, they had known each other for years before. Legolas and you have only just met a few weeks before. No, more like just one week!

"Coming, Daeloth?" calls Legolas, looking over his shoulder as Mexle hurries him along. "Wait," he tells the Forest-child, "Daeloth has stopped."

"Oh, it's nothing," you answer, unable to look Legolas in the eye. "I am but tired."

The look on Mexle's face clearly tells you exactly what she thinks of that. Legolas catches the expression and turns on her. "She is still weak from an Orc attack that happened a day ago. She saved the Fellowship with her quick thinking and sharp fighting." His voice holds admiration for you, and you can't stop an embarrassed blush.

"Ah." Mexle shoots you a look of pure venom, and you almost laugh at the realization that bursts into your head---she is jealous, and considers you competition for Legolas' affections. With an effort, she pastes on a smile and glances back at Legolas. "So," she purrs, "who is this... Fellowship?"

You toss a look at Legolas, hoping that he knows enough not to relay all of your information: why you are here, who the Fellowship really is, etc.
1112112121212121211111111111211.title: She is.

11121121212121212111111111112111.content:
No worries...Legolas knows to withhold some information. Carefully, he spins a tale of the Fellowship banding together to fight the Orcs. Not a lie, but not exactly the whole truth, either. When he finishes, Mexle seems to look at both of you in a new light. "You were very brave," she murmurs, giving you a sideways glance. You are pleased to see a bit of fear in her eyes. You know she won't underestimate you again.

The three of you continue on in silence. You won't admit it, but this part of the Forest is kind of creeping you out. It's dark and wet, and things in the shadows move. Mexle keeps walking on, her shoulders straight and her chin lifted. 'No way this girl is braver than me', you mutter, so you force yourself to walk on. Soon you find yourselves walking through what seems to be a tunnel of branches woven tightly together. Mexle stops in front of a branch. "We are here," she says shortly.

"Where?" you and Legolas ask at the same time.

"Here!" Mexle replies, exasperated. She grabs the branch in her hand and begins to snap it. Then she stops. "You may only enter if you are a Dennali, or someone to whom a Dennali owes a debt. I'm sorry, I have just remembered this."

"What? So...Daeloth can't go in?" Legolas shoots you a startled look. Mexle merely shrugs, but you catch a glimpse of triumph in her eyes. She is lying. Isn't she? You glance back at Legolas pleadingly, who is staring at Mexle with a cold, calculating expression. "I shall not go in without her," he tells Mexle sharply. "It's both of us or no one."

"for a price of course" Jakk breaks in.

"there have been Orcs roaming the outskirts of the city but our scouts have driven them away,and every boy and man has been called upon to defend the city and I have been called upon but I don't know how to fight will you teach me"? Jakk asks, looking at Legolas.

111211212121212121111111111121111211.content:
"I will," says Legolas softly, looking down at the young boy. "Of this you have my word."

Pleased, Jakk nods and waves a hand. "This way, then," he tells you. "I'll see to it that you find...what were you looking for, anyway?"

"Two hobbit friends of ours were lost in the forest. Your sister said that they were here. Could you take us to them? They're small-ish people," you add belatedly, as a look of confusion crosses Jakk's face. "Hobbits are not normal-sized people. They are even smaller than you are."

"Oh! Frodo and Sam," he shouts with delight. "They are very nice to me. If you're friends of theirs, then you're friends of mine."

"And mine!" pipes in Mexle, her feathers obviously ruffled by the way she's been left out. Jakk shoots her a look and points toward a hut---probably where 'Matamay' is waiting for Mexle's help. "Fare-thee-well, Legolas," she tells the elf shyly. "And...you too, Daeloth."

"Of course. The pleasure is mine," you tell her politely but without any real warmth. She walks quickly off, and Jakk begins herding you towards the center of the village, chattering excitedly about this or that. It's obvious that he looks up to Legolas as a hero, and he seems to hold you in high regard as well.

"Here we are," he finally says, gesturing towards a building that sits in the very center of the village. At one glance it's plain to see that it is meant as a jail, or at least a holding-place of some kind. "Frodo and Sam are inside. And, um, excuse me sir..."

"You can call me Legolas," he of that name replies gently.

"Ah. Okay. Legolas. While Miss Daeloth is attending to your friends, maybe you could...you know..." Jakk casts a hopeful glance at Legolas's sheathed elven daggers, and then at his bow and arrows. "Give me a few pointers?"

Legolas glances at you, and you shrug in a go-ahead kind of way. "Of course, Master Jakk," he tells the boy. "Simply show me a place to start." Delighted, Jakk grasps Legolas's sleeve and drags him off.

When they are gone, you walk up to the door of the jail and knock tentitavely. "Hello?" you call softly. "Frodo, Sam...are you in there?"

11121121212121212111112.content:
You slowly awaken inside a dark, dank...cell of some sort. You think prison...or perhaps dungeon. Yes dungeon. Everything points to that as you slowly gather your thoughts and become aware of the entrapments.

Lying there, you conjure last remembrances, piecing together fleeting flashes. Your neck aches considerably, and your lungs draw the thick, sickly air here, weakly. You hear the sound of your own lungs rasping in high pitched whistles.

You remember a woods...rocks tumbling violently...orcs storming...feeling faint...talking to Aragorn...the sight of a terrible dark wizard. Your chest pounds.

Fear sweeps over you, but eventually your racing heart slows to psychologically manageable thuds. This is no time to panic, you try to champion yourself. "I am in some sort of danger...must find a way to get out of here," you command to yourself silently.

You grope around, still lying flat, noticing you are on a bed of roughly hewn planks. The bed of planks are attached by rusty chains, angularly upward, to a cold, moist wall of stone your hand finds off to your left. With labor you lift your head a bit, enough to look longways in the direction of your feet and you note the flickering, dancing glow of light through a square and barred window. Where the torch is. Must be the door. Hallway out there. "But to where does it go?" you ask yourself in silence.

Tears well in your eyes as you rest your aching head back down. No pillow.

"Where am I?" you say to yourself in serious self-pity. "What is to become of me?"

Only another minute goes by when you notice you are very, very hungry, and wonder how long you have been here. Hours? Days? You simply do not know.

With great effort, you sit yourself upright on the bed, legs dangling over. Just barely do they touch a stone floor in the darkness beneath you. You stand and immediately feel faint. Yes, you were hurt badly by the orcs and who knows what else befell you after you passed out?

Somehow you manage to move yourself with small careful steps around the room, hands outreached. You find there is nothing but that stiff plank bed in here. You choose the corner furthest from your bed and relieve yourself there.

You walk back over to your bed, standing there next to it after you bump into its edges, when you notice how dry your throat is. You are dehydrated. Cupping your forehead, you feel hot...feverish. Dizzy you are....the square barred window moving of its own accord...there, and back here again. Terrible dizziness. The world is spinning. Hangovers are far, far better.

You have no choice but to lie back down.

Hungry, hurting, dry, weak, cold, feverish, worrying...you want to forget your miserable situation. You close your eyes and want to force yourself to forget. And to sleep.

After one hour, with tears rolling off the sides of your face and sometimes behind your ears, you fall asleep.
11121121212121212111112.title: The Dungeon

choices: He calms down and explains to you what has happened
He works himself into a frenzy and strikes you
111211212121212121111121.content:
You dream of swirling darkness, anger, menace...blood and tears, some of them yours...and evil: choking evil, so thick and one-minded, so set on destroying anything and everything that stands in its way---eager to do anything to get what it wants. "What DO you want?" you scream in terror, unable to grasp its scale of hatred. It is almost with a sense of relief that you are jolted out of your sleep, escaping the suffocating evil that haunted you. But as you blink to clear your eyes of tears and grogginess, you realize that it would almost be better to face the things you had just woken up from. At least they were just a dream.

The dark wizard is there, bigger than life, right in your tiny cell. His eyes pierce through you, and you feel as if they are stripping you apart and seeing what lies within---your secrets, thoughts, hopes and dreams. You begin to feel sick, and you try to focus on something else. For the first time, you notice that the wizard isn't alone. Three huge Orcs have escorted him, and they are all snarling at you as if they would love to see you suffer. No, focusing on them isn't helping. So you throw your glance desperately around the room, trying to catch hold of something else that will save you from the scrutinizing eyes of the wizard...

Then you see him. There, just outside the open door of the cell, huddles a male Human, looking as broken as anyone can be. His back is bent like an old man's and his hair hangs in sweaty tendrils over his face. His hands are clenched inside his restraning irons, as if he still holds on to a slim thread of defiance. He coughs, a long, bone-rattling hack, and it makes you want to clasp your hands over your ears to block out the heart-wrenching sound. His face is still obscured, but you have no wish to see what is under his veil of hair. You imagine a brittle, wrinkle-lined face, with sunken eyes that have been through too much suffering in this lifetime. Probably some poor farmer, out of whom they tried to get information, you think sadly. You have seen many people put through torture and died from it---or worse, they lived, forever cursed with their marks of unimagineable pain and trial.

"Daeloth," hisses a voice. The wizard. "Yes, I know your name, and I know it of all the Fellowship. Nothing escapes me. Nothing will, not even a pitiful excuse for a king," he continues in that awful sound that makes you think of fingernails scratching a stone wall.

King? you wonder. There's a connection here, but your feverish brain can't put it together. Nothing seems to matter except the surprisingly young-looking face of the dark wizard. His eyes, though, are centuries old and are restrained by forces of evil too strong for you to comprehend. "You do not know who I am," he remarks, with a hint of displeasure in his voice. You dare to shake your head no. "Soon everyone will," he screeches with an air of almost-dementia. "I am Schimquyth, the greatest wizard that was, is, and ever will be, in the history of Middle Earth!"
111211212121212121111121.title: Schimquyth

1112112121212121211111211.content:
A few terrifying moments pass, with Schimquyth cursing the world and you cowering on your cot. Finally, the wizard turns to look at you. "I suppose you're wondering how you came to be here," he remarks casually, once again calm and in control. You shrug, matching his don't-care attitude. You have decided that there will be no more cowardice...on the outside, anyways. I will not break in his eyes, you tell yourself resolutely; even while you are trembling inside. But to Schimquyth, you are the picture of stubborn.

"Ah, little warrior, you have courage. But there is no need for bravado here. I shall give a narration of what befell you and your precious Fellowship, and then we will see how you act then." He clears his throat and, in spite of yourself, you lean forward expectantly.

"I had planned on your destruction. I had no use for you, and you were merely an annoyance. So I told my Orc leader to dispose of you. Unfortunately, that pesky king of yours—Aralagona, right?—insisted on barging through and saving you. Hm, I suppose chivalry isn't dead after all." Schimquyth pauses for a nasty chuckle at his own stupid joke. Over in the corner, the human shifts from side to side, and you wonder if he is listening as intently as you are. Schimquyth continues: "After he had taken care of the Orcleader, King Ariagorna---"

"It's Aragorn!" you burst out. "His name is Aragorn, and I will not have you mocking our king." The beaten man jerks and starts to look up at you, but the guard Orcs backhand him against the wall. You decide that he did not know that you were in the company of the King and was surprised by this...

"Aahhhggghhh!" You let out an involuntary scream of shocked pain as a bolt of electricity jolts through your entire body, scrambling your thoughts and causing your limbs to go weak. After your head stops ringing and your vision clears, you see Schimquyth standing over you, his staff crackling with blue lightning. He bends down so his eyes are level with yours.

"I suggest you keep your opinions to yourself," he whispers menacingly. “Now! Where was I? Ah, yes… After the king took care of the Orcleader, he helped you up, blah blah blah. Then you fainted while trying to walk. Ha! The fragility of women is rivaled only by the flowers that grow by the riverbank,” he remarks. You clench your fists but, remembering the blast of lightning, remain silent. “The king tried to carry you over to the rest of the Fellowship. I saw you, though, and got tired of the wizard I was fighting. Quite a frail old thing, he is. So I slipped past his defenses and froze his limbs and body, rendering him helpless. Then I told the Orcs to pick you and your king up, and escort you back here. Along with the rest of the Fellowship, of course,” Schimquyth adds, looking shrewdly at you. “Let’s see, there were the two hobbits---Frodo and Sam, correct?---along with, erm…help me out, dear warrior, I can’t remember. There was also a very annoying elf. What was his name?”

“Le---” you start to blurt out. But an outburst startles you into silence.

The man who had, so far, been hunched over in the cell suddenly comes to life. “No!” he shouts, making an attempt to stand. “Don’t tell him anything, Daeloth.” You gasp as you realize that the voice is familiar. He grasps the walls and struggles to his feet, showing his face.

“My lord…Aragorn?!”
1112112121212121211111211.title: An explanation and a threat

choices: You leap at Schimquyth to try and knock him over
11121121212121212111112111.content:
Your breath catches in your throat as the beaten man rises. But he’s not just any man---he is King Aragorn of Middle Earth! Beside that fact, he’s Aragorn your comrade and friend, with whom you traveled many miles and have exchanged many conversations, jokes and sympathies. It breaks your heart to see him reduced to this, a man that has been tortured many times and yet still holds on to something---anything…

Schimquyth whirls around, his surprise evident. “What is he doing up?” he screams at the guard Orcs. When they stare dumbly at Aragorn and then each other, the wizard snorts in impatience and rage. “Never mind,” he snarls, “I shall take care of him myself.” He raises his staff at Aragorn, who stares back calmly in the face of death…literally. “Perhaps I won’t kill you, my king,” Schimquyth snarls mockingly. “I still have need of you. But a few missing limbs won’t lower your price. Nor will madness. I can make you mad, son of Arathorn; and I speak not of anger.” The wizard levels his staff right at Aragorn’s chest and starts to mutter ancient words. The tip of his staff glows red.
11121121212121212111112111.title: Continue....................

choices: You try to escape out the door
111211212121212121111121111.content:
You can't just stand there and do nothing as an evil wizard is about to do something supernatural to your king...and friend! Desperately, you hurl yourself off of the cot and right into Schimquyth's back, knocking him over. The effect is immediate. Just as a glowing red ball of light shoots out of the staff is when you knock into him, jarring his aim. The ball of light gets moved off-course and instead of hitting Aragorn, it flies into one of the Orc guards. He takes a few stutter-steps back and falls flat on his back. Everything seems frozen for a little.

Then he starts to scream---a horrible sound that pierces through your mind and speaks of terrible things seen. The infected Orc rolls on the ground, still screaming and now babbling incoherent sentences and sounds. "Aragorn..." you mutter, shocked. That could have been him. He looks at you and then at the amazed wizard.

"A mistake," wheezes Schimquyth. He is incredibly furious. "You have made a terrible mistake. And you shall pay!" He raises his staff again, but this time it is pointed at you. Out of the corner of your eye you see movement, but if it's Aragorn he's too late---or is he?---everything's happening too fast---

"Ooooff," you grunt as someone tackles you. A thin blade shoots over the air where your head had been seconds before. You use your momentum to turn your fall into a forward roll and leap to your feet. Aragorn---for it was he who tackled you, of course---follows suit.

"Let's go," he tells you simply, motioning to the now-open door. When you hesitate, he adds, "it's now or never." You know this is true, but still... Schimquyth is so angry he can barely focus, but this may make him even more dangerous. If you run out the door now it could mean certain death. But if you stay, the outcome may be almost the same.
111211212121212121111121111.title: Try and save Aragorn

1112112121212121211111211111.content:
"All right," you agree. "Let's get out of here." Together you dash past the still-gibbering Orc and race for the open door. The remaining two Orcs step in front of your route of escape, and the look on their ugly faces says that they're ready to get revenge. You hesitate, but Aragorn charges ahead without stopping. You shrug and follow---what other option do you have? So you are right on Aragorn's tail as he rushes towards the guards. The speed, momentum and determination of you two combined with the surprise of the attack is enough to propel back the pair of Orcs, and you both stumble out into the hallway. The stone pathway stretches out before you, leading to freedom!...that is, if you can escape the now-enraged Orcs. But why bother with minor details? You and Aragorn sprint down the hall as if your life depends on it. Which, of course, it does.

"Stop them," roars a voice. Schimquyth emerges from the cell, his face flushed with rage. "Catch them," he screams again, gesturing to the Orcs. Grunting determinedly, they hoist their weapons and pound after you.

"Run," you call to Aragorn. "They're coming!" The two of you lengthen your stride, but you notice that your king is flagging. You suddenly remember his state and realize that he has been tortured and food/sleep-deprived. He can't keep on like this forever, or even much longer. And the Orcs are gaining. "Come on," you pant to him. "Keep going, don't give up!" Aragorn looks at you, his breath coming short and hard.

"I...can't..." he groans, clutching his side. When he pulls his hand away, it is dark with blood from an old wound opened again. "Daeloth, you have to go," he grunts. "Get the Fellowship and come back here. You can make it. I'll just slow you down."

"No!" you tell him. "This is no time for that. You're the king; of course you can make it! Come on, my lord, just a little bit further!" When he slows even more, you grab his arm and begin to haul him bodily with you. But you won't be able to keep that up if you're going to escape, and Aragorn knows it. He wrenches himself free.

A horrible laugh floats through the hall, and you look back and see the Orcs are even nearer. Schimquyth is enjoying this immensely. His dark eyes bore into you, and you feel a terrible rage well up. He can't win. He can't.

"Daeloth, as your king, I am commanding you: leave!" Aragorn shouts.
1112112121212121211111211111.title: The Choice

11121121212121212111112111111.content:
"No," you choke out. But he will not move, and the Orcs are only a few yards away. Aragorn raises his hand and strikes you, much to your shock.

"Go!" he roars. The pain jolts you into action, and you start to run uncertainly. You glance over your shoulder, and Aragorn yells, "Run, Daeloth! Don't look back!"

You don't.
11121121212121212111112111111.title: Leave him

11121121212121212111112111112.content:
"And as your friend, I'm telling you: no!" you answer hotly. You've made your choice. You'll stay with Aragorn and try to persuade him to leave with you. And if he doesn't...well, you'll just have to stay and try to fight the attackers off. You drop to a knee to plead some sense into your king. "Aragorn," you say, speaking low and fast. "Listen to me. You can't stay here, at the mercy of a dark wizard and his Orcs! Even if somehow you do survive, they will break you and you will never be the same. Do you remember when the king of Rohan was being controlled by Saruman? Do you doubt that something similar will happen to you? You cannot let that happen to you, to your subjects, to Middle Earth! This time there will be no One Ring to destroy that will bring you back." Aragorn looks at you but says nothing.

The Orcs are no more than ten yards away. Desperately you keep try another tact. "Frodo!" you shout. "Legolas...Gimli...Gandalf...Sam...Merry...Pippin! You can't desert them, the Fellowship, now! And what of Arwen?" you ask. "Will you give up and die, and let her waste away in grief? Will you let yourself be taken over by Schimquyth and eventually kill her yourself?" You have gotten Aragorn's attention now. He had pulled in a sharp breath at the mention of Arwen's name, and now he lets it out. "And...and what of me?" you ask, so softly you wonder if you had actually spoken it aloud. "I am forfeiting my life to help you, my lord. My friend."

Aragorn bows his head, then reaches down and offers you a hand. "We are equals, Daeloth," he tells you. "Do not bow to me. For surely you have saved my life and the lives of others just now."

"That will all be for naught if we don't leave now," you tell him in a shaky voice. Your emotions were punched down while you were speaking, because you had to believe that Aragorn would listen to you. But now you realize that it was possible that he might have turned you away. You swallow...best not to dwell on those thoughts now. Best to dwell on those Orcs that are just a few yards away. "Come on!" you shout. Aragorn takes a breath, nods, and begins to run down the hallway with you.

Schimquyth's laughter is cut short as he realizes that his two captives are getting away. The Orcs were ready for an easy victory, so they are also surprised, and they stop for a few seconds in shock. "Don't stop, you idiots!" curses Schimquyth. "I will have to do this myself," he says to himself. He raises his staff.

Aragorn notices. "Look out!" he warns. "We have to get out of his line of fire!" Just ahead, the hallway branches off. Now there are three paths: one going straight, one to the left and one to the right. The straight one is not an option, as Schimquyth would still be able to see you. It's either the left or the right. Which do you choose?
11121121212121212111112111112.title: Stay with Aragorn

111211212121212121111121111121.content:
"This way!" you shout, making a split-second decision. You turn to the left tunnel, and after a moment's hesitation, Aragorn follows you. Now the only sounds are your ragged breathing and the thump of your feet on the stones. This tunnel is dark and insufficiently lit, and you can barely see where you're headed. Behind you, an Orc horn begins to blow, no doubt calling for help from his comrades. The sound only serves to double your speed.

"Why did you choose this way?" asks Aragorn.

"Why not?" you return. Aragorn nods in acceptance. Then you both lapse into silence for a while, all your thoughts concentrated on getting out of here. You sneak a glance at Aragorn and note that he is, once again, slowing down. He needs a break. Without stopping, you twist your head around and check behind you. There are no Orcs to be seen, and that gives you a bad feeling. Could it somehow be a trap?

"Daeloth," Aragorn pants. "Daeloth. I have to rest." He slows and then stops, out of breath. He shakes his head in disgust. "There was a time that I could continue on like this for hours and not feel tired."

"Well, during that time, you were not beaten and wounded, am I correct?" Despite your light tone, you are anxious to get going again. Should you let Aragorn rest a little more, or should you insist that you both move on?
111211212121212121111121111121.title: The left

111211212121212121111122.content:
"Daeloth.......Daeloth........You must wake up." A voice, soft but insistent, butts into your dreams. You roll over, wanting to lose yourself again in the dream you were having: Orcs are everywhere but none can harm you. You are invincible, smashing through their weapons and defenses with the slightest of ease. Legolas is there too---why, you have no idea. Certainly he is just a friend. Worth dreaming about, but just a friend...right? In the dream you can see his sparkling eyes, hear his laugh as he effortlessly cuts down another Orc.

"Daeloth! Get up." That stupid voice! It won't go away. It's cutting through your dreams like a hot knife, and you feel yourself beginning to rise to conciousness. No, no, you plead silently; just leave me. "DAELOTH!"

Your eyes fly open. "What? Where?" you sputter, reaching for your twin blades. But they're not there. Neither are your daggers. Oh, right, you're in a dungeon. Of course they would take your weapons. But then, who was speaking to you? "I'm going crazy," you mutter. "Absolutely, finally, crazy." Because when you think about it, that voice sounded just like Gandalf the White's.

A low laugh floats through the cell. "It is I, Daeloth. Look up." You wrinkle your eyebrows, but obey---what other choice do you have? When your eyes settle on the figure, you let out a disbelieving snort. It really is him! So was the dungeon just a dream? Quickly you glance around. No, you're still in your cell, with the door barred securely.

"Gandalf, how?" you ask simply. Another figure joins the first. "Aragorn!" you exclaim softly.

"We have not much time." Your king speaks softly and swiftly. "We are not really here. This is simply a spell Gandalf has conjured up: it will not last much longer. Listen well. You were captured and brought here. The dark wizard's name is Tolxumith; this is all we know about him."

"Wait," you blurt out. "Was I the only one captured on the battlefield?"

"No," Gandalf answers.
111211212121212121111122.title: Gandalf and Aragorn...not really

choices: The Orcs stop at your cell
1112112121212121211111221.content:
"Legolas was captured as well. He is with you...not in your cell, but in the dungeon," Gandalf tells you. "We know not why Tolxumith captured only you and Legolas---a mere woman and an elf." You raise an eyebrow but decide to let that one slide. For now, anyway. "...but it cannot be good," the White Wizard finishes. "You mush find Legolas and get out in all haste."

"Aaannnndd..." you motion for them to continue. They stare back at you. Finally you give up on them figuring it out on their own. "The door. The door needs to be op-en before I can get out," you remind them, as if you would a small child. Amazing, how you can be deep underground trapped in a dungeon that's located who-knows-where and still be sarcastic. It's a dark gift.

"Forgive me, Daeloth," Gandalf tells you. "Hold on just a moment..." He closes his eyes in concentration---and disappears. At the exact same moment, though, the door flies open. You guess that he could not keep up two major spells at once, but you still feel a little forgotten. Oh well. As long as the door is open and you can get out of here, then you're fine. Cautiously, you slide off the bed and creep towards the doorway. You examine the door and notice that the lock is shattered. Good---this means that you can close the door and still get out of here. As quietly as you can, you ease out the doorway and into the hall beyond. A few torches attempt to pierce the gloom but most of the hallways are still immersed in shadow.

Then you hear something. It sounds like footsteps. Your heart leaps---did Gandalf and Aragorn visit Legolas as well?---but it crashes down when you realize that these footsteps are much too heavy and loud to be those of an elf's, especially an escaped elf. Your other options are the Dark Wizard (Tolxumith) or some Orc guards. Neither one is promising, but if you have a choice you will take the Orcs. Even Urrak-hai would be better than a wizard. You experienced firsthand the powers of a dark wizard, and you're not anxious to do it again. Orcs you can fight and you might have a chance of winning, but Tolxumith...no way.

Wait a minute. Fight Orcs with what? You are weaponless. Cursing your terrible luck, you sneak back into the cell and ease the door shut. "Keep walking, keep walking, keep walking," you silently urge the footsteps. They're closer now, and you surmise that they are indeed Orcs: three or four of them, judging by the sounds.
1112112121212121211111221.title: You're free!!...wait, no

11121121212121212111112212.content:
Despite your silent orders, the footsteps slow, then stop by your cell. "Is this the one?" an Orc asks in guttural tones.

"Yes," another grunts. "The Master requests that this one be brought to him as well as the elf." So Legolas is here! Quietly, you edge back to your bed. How are you going to get out of this one? You have no weapons or anything to fight with. But to your great surprise, as you sit on the cot, you hear the gentle clink of metal on metal from your back. Your twin blades! Somehow, you've gotten them back. Gandalf...of course. He would have known that sending you, weaponless, out to face a dark wizard and Orc guards wouldn't have been smart. So he's given you your swords back! And---you feel around your belt. Yes, and your daggers, as well. Confidently, you stand, ready to face down the Orcs.

The door creaks open, and the first of the guards step in. "Where are you..." he calls nastily. "Come on, I promise not ta hurt you. Yet." He adds a chuckle at the end of the sentence.

"Or ever," you speak out of the darkness. He frowns and furrows his brow. "Here, I'll put you out of your misery," you say. Whish-whish! Your blades whip through the air and effectively cut his head from his shoulders.
11121121212121212111112212.title: The Orcs stop at your cell

choices: Legolas comes to help you out
111211212121212121111122121.content:
The now-headless Orc stays on his feet for about a second, then he falls to the ground with a loud thump. The other guards outside jerk their heads up, aware that something's wrong. "What's going on?" one growls, hefting his weapon. When there's no answer, he takes a step into your cell. You lift your blades, ready for him; but he sees you just in time to narrowly avoid your swords. He roars a command to the other two Orcs, and now you have three to go against!

"No matter," you grunt to yourself, sidestepping to avoid a blow. It's just a little more time out of your day. You've got plenty to spare. Besides, you tell yourself, look at it as training. With, you know, real Orcs. You crouch on the ground as an Orc weapon swings over your head, then you explode upwards, catching that particular Orc off-guard. You deal him a glancing blow, meant to wound not kill, and he roars in anger. Quickly you block his weapon with one of your own, and with your other sword in hand, you drive your blade home. He slumps to the ground, life draining out of his cruel eyes. One down, two to go.
The remaining Orcs begin to close in on you, and you realize that fighting in the cell is to your disadvantage. The Orcs are large and can cover more room, and while you're agile, no one is good enough to avoid two swinging Orc blades in an 8-by-5 foot room.

You leap onto the cot, then jump as high as you can off of it, aiming for the door. You just make it before one Orc takes a murderous swing at where you were standing a second ago. Out in the hallway, you realize that it isn't much wider than the cell. You could make a run for it, but then the Orcs would alert everyone of your presence. Better to leave no witnesses. You stand and face the door, ready for the guards.
111211212121212121111122121.title: Ambush the Orcs!

11121122.content:
You sigh in relief to see the dark haired halfling staring up at you curiously.

"Forgive me, I did not think anyone else would be roaming this path," He told her bowing his head to her.

"It is nothing to worry about Mr. Baggins," You tell him with a soft smile and a bow. You knew of his journey into Mordor as he did yours and the respect that you each held for one another was great.

Frodo smiled and you silently offered for him to join you.

"This evil seems to dwell everywhere, even here in Imladeris." You began as you both walked together.

"I feel it as well, it is though it controls the very air we breathe." He said looking up at you with his clear blue eyes.

"Another evil begins its war to take over the struggling poeples of Middle Earth as though Sauron was just divertion, to keep its fowlness conceled by Sauron's darkness." You agreed.

Frodo nodded. "I have too thought that, it is perhaps the very power that created Sauron, we will be almost powerles against it."

You frowned, "Almost, but not quite, perhaps now is the time to plan for the worst."

"Is that how you see it Daeloth?" A voice said from behind.

You and Frodo both turn to see...
11121122.title: Darkening Thoughts

111211221.content:
"Yes, Gandalf. Very much so." replies Daeloth, slightly rigidly, almost disrespectfully for being in such revered company as Gandalf the White.

She continues, "Forgive me if I sound a bit forward, Lord Gandalf. But, I feel what I feel."

Gandalf raises his right eyebrow in mild perplexity at the woman's sudden shift to use the respectful title, Lord. He takes a long draw from his lit pipe filled with Old Tovy, deftly exhales a perfect ring off to his left, then replies in rather fatherly, understanding fashion, "Rest assured, my dear Daeloth, Sauron is no longer. He will never again return to Middle Earth. Trust me. I know this to be true."

Frodo interjects, "How do you know this, Gandalf? I just conveyed a similar thought to Daeloth before you walked into view. I mean, I too have been sensing the hand of Sauron. Not so dissimilar from the way I felt when I was ringbearer."

Gandalf shifts his glance toward Frodo, "Ah yes, Master Baggins, you indeed have experienced the invisible forces of evil before. Twas a terrible burden you bore, way back when." He pauses to take another draw of Tovy. "But today we have a different anomaly stirring. While neither I nor Elrond can quite define this...this new force of darkness, I must be quick to dispel your and Daeloth's entertainment of the idea that Sauron is alive. He is, quite simply, dead. And that's that."
111211221.title: New Force of Darkness

choices: You know you must help defend Middle Earth
12.content:
Elves

         Ahhhâ€¦of course. You are of the wise, elegant, and immortal race of elves. This means that you have extraordinary senses, you are one with nature, and you have healing powers. If you are female, your beauty is beyond words, and your grace is indescribable. For the male elves, you are swift warriors. You do much damage with your elven daggers, but it is with your bow that you have much skill, and where you are unavoidably deadly to any enemy. Almost all elves have the gift of song, and your voice can lure creatures of all sorts into peaceful trances. But as an elf you mean no harm to those who mean no harm to you. However, you defend yourself when the time calls for it, and you are there to defend Middle Earth when the time calls for it as well.

         This time definitely calls for defense. An evil is lurking about in Middle Earth once again. Its reign is nowhere near strong, so far, but it is growing. The wicked creature that brings such hate, cruelty, and malice is clever. It is hiding far enough in shadow that its identity has not yet been seen. Yet the remaining orcs and other evil creatures that survived from Sauron's time in power have multiplied, and they have already joined forces with this unknown evil.

         As the crowd of various races seat themselves, the rooms goes silent. Elrond's voice fills the open room; you listen attentively, knowing the importance and secrecy of all of his meetings.

         "It has been a great while since I have called a council of such significance. Not since Sauron's threat to overtake Middle Earth has such an evil come unto these lands. We were fortunate enough to know of Sauron's plan to find the One Ring and we successfully destroyed it. But with this evil, we do not know what its plans are, what it looks like, or even if it has a human form. We call upon the elves, dwarves, wizards, men, and now hobbits," Elrond says as he looks over to Frodo," as well as any other free people of Middle Earth to defend all that is good. Those who are with us from the Fellowship of The Ring have already vowed to lead this quest, but they cannot do it alone. We need almost all of you to help, but there are probably few of you who are brave enough to do so, " He pauses for a moment, with a look of concern on his face, "I will give you all a few moments to think out your decision.

Now you must make your first decision. Will you help defend all that is good in Middle Earth?
