choices: Travel to the Misty Mountains, and the land of Isengard
1211.content:
"Darrian Buck, what are you getting yourself into?" you think as you look around the council at all the famous and near famous faces. Reaching behind your shoulder you feel the reassuring weight of your mandolin strapped to your back. "A muscian and a lover is what you are" as you remember the few lovely maids that you entertained at winter solstice celebration. The council drones on as you are lost to your imaginations.

"And the second, great grand nephew to Elrond himself" you can hear your father reminding you, just as he had a hundred times before. Still my skill at shooting tourney targets isn't the same as shooting at live targets. . . .specially ones that shoot back. No matter though, I am here and a defender of the family name if nothing else.

"AND I need two groups of defenders" you hear Elrond bellow. "One to clean out the mines of Morier", he pauses as you are jolted out of your reverie.

You hope against hope that the next option is a bit less terrifying. Elves are not fond of being trapped under tons of rock and dirt.


"The other will travel to the Southern end of the Misty Mountains and scout the land of Isengard."

Gods be good, what kind of a choice is this? Either burried under tons of rubble with thousands of orcs, or assailing the birth place of the wicked orc-hybrids, and the wizard Saruman.

The members of the council begin to seperate to 2 different sides of the room. You decide to:
1211.title: Defender of the families honor

choices: Anthiala notices something and advises Ongleth on a route
Dremurth chooses the way to go at Ongleth's request
12111.content:
Nearly a month passed before our party, commissioned by my great grand uncle Lord Elrond himself, arrived at the base of the rocky peaks that lay above Moria.

We arrived in greater number than when we left Rivendell. En route and roughly a fortnight ago we had encountered a fleeing band of nine dwarves. They were remnants of a massive orc attack on a dwarven military enclave originally numbering about two hundred. The enclave's destination and plan had been the same as ours. Enter Moria and rid its glorious halls of filth. They had not known of Lord Elrond's recent council in Rivendell. They were pleased to hear of Elrond's plans, more proof of the renewed alliance between Middle Earth's dwarves and elves.

But the dwarves met with tragedy in a mountain pass. The enclave walked right into a valley being monitored by scouts from the the right flank of a horde of nearly two thousand orcs and hobgoblins. Forthwith an assaulting wave of the orcs and hobgoblins swept down into the valley. About an hour of carnage ensued in this entrapment. With total massacre in plain view, and with all hope nearly lost, the surviving nine's leader, Sergeant Dremurth Grammett, ingeniously thought up a plan to lure scores of blood hungry orcs through a narrow ravine passage, above which well-posted sentries would hurl rocks down onto the pursuing enemy. This hastily concocted strategy of withdrawal whilst counter-attacking worked to a point. Sadly, just Dremurth himself and eight others escaped out the other end of the ravine passage.

"What became of the rest of my dwarven comrades, I do not know", sighed Dremurth. "As for us, we were mighty lucky to have survived that ghastly melee."

"Aye, but we took down a baker's dozen to maybe twenty or more, each of us, didn't we, Sarge?", bellowed Axel Gravestone, pounding his double-bladed war axe to his broad chest, smiling.

Dremurth interjects, "That we did, that we did, Axel. But, just remember you juvenile twit, I split the skull of that one just about to impale you from your hind. And for that, I have this bloody scratch from the one who was flitting his cheap, skinny blade on my left." Dremurth splays a nasty looking cut on his left forearm. "The ratbreath who did this to me breathes no more. I dealt with him soon after I halved your foe, Axel. I removed his puny bug-eyed head, I did. Arghh!"

The nine broke out in laughter. Soon enough, they were befriended by the commissioned party, always in need of a few more allies. Together, they now numbered sixty-three. Twenty-five dwarves, eighteen humans, fourteen elves, five hobbits and one wizard.

The leader of our commission was my father, Ongleth Buck. Without delay he had appointed our new arrivee Dremurth Grammett as navigator, owing to the dwarf's knowledge of Moria and its surroundings.

All had known the way into Moria that the Fellowship of the Ring had chosen was blocked, due to that scuffle with the tentacled swamp monster. Neither, too, could the Fellowship's way out be used for re-entry, as the bridge to the interior there had been destroyed by the Balroc. Originally Ongleth planned on entering via the Grimmstone Neck, an exceedingly high up entry requiring first a rather arduous climb to a snowcap, then a twelve hundred foot repel into a circular, thirty yards wide ice-lined opening, till the floor of an interior shelf could be landed upon. In fact, much of the gear they had brought from Rivendell had to do with the initial, mountainous climb (snowshoes, pick axes and such), the repel (lots of rope), and the weather (sufficient skins to stay warm).

But a new plan of entering Moria would soon unfold.

On the second night traveling with the band of nine, still many days from Moria, Ongleth had held a meeting with Dremurth Grammett, myself, two of the elder humans, Arthur Traxler and Gregson Bidwell, and the female elven seer, Anthiala Ensali. Anthiala was known for her intellect and alluring beauty, but most of all, extreme hatred of all things evil. There were six of us in all.

To predicate the meeting, father had an assistant, a hobbit by the name of Gabber Dantwiddly, prepare us a fine dinner of greens, wine, bread, cheese and freshly caught rainbow trout from the river that snaked through the valley far below our encampment, which was perched high on a bluff, safe from surprise attacks.

Our meeting place was in a soft clearing beneath a great two hundred foot pine, a stone's throw from the edge of the bluff. The view from here was nothing less than spectacular. From this vantage point it was hard to imagine trouble was again stirring in Middle Earth. The sun was still shining from the west as we sat down to dinner. There was maybe one more hour of light before it would set. Taking in this gorgeous view of nature I thought back to just weeks earlier, when I along with my elfin brethren were convinced, owing to the destruction of Sauron, that our elfin tenure in this, the Blessed Land of Middle Earth, was complete, and that, at last, we would soon set sail for the timeless shores of Sacred Valinor.

As the six waited for Gabber's trays of bounty, I played my mandola and concocted on the spot a tribute song to the group at hand, the idea being to lighten things up a bit and prepare us mentally for what was to be an important meeting, and change in plans.

The Great Pine Meeting

by Darrius Buck, mandolaist


Oh Father Buck, why do you call us here?
We sit here, your point still unclear
We think it must be important
Yet we sit, waiting, hungry, nigh on insolent

Among us is Dremurth, sergeant to nine
Full of brandy, time out of mind
A belly not yet full, he grumbles
A fish not yet consumed, more he grumbles

Among us is Arthur, eldest man, master in sword
There he swings it, getting a bit bored
What will he say when your meeting starts?
Glad the assistant didn't bring beans in his carts

Among us is Gregson, sneakiest that walks on two
Cannot wait to grab something to chew
Hand him a warhammer to swing
And that would be the last I ever sing

Among us is Anthiala, fairest and wisest
If we eat too much she will despise us
And we wouldn't want that, and that we wouldn't want
To become the gamely game that she would hunt

Last of all, me, your mandola player
Singing and strumming layer upon layer
If the food comes not in a minute here
Father Buck, you will have offspring to fear


And they all, at least the males, laughed and exchanged several jokes upon me, not leaving out the quips that I was skinny as a rail (heard that one before) and had ears large enough such that, if bent sideways, I could fly. When I had sung the verse to Anthiala she had feigned a cutesy smirk at me. Now with the ridicule being shoveled upon me by the others, particulary by Dremurth, all she could do was giggle and enjoy my gauntlet.

The food soon came, and we all ate heartily. Grabber went back for more. Twice.

After dinner, the meeting took place and wound on enough to where Gabber had to light a fire for us as the last of the sun's rays had been cut off by the distant hills to the west. We finished about an hour after dark. Much was talked about concerning the welfare of the commission, supplies and food rationing, dissemination of various duties, plans for what to do inside Moria, and so on, but the main point of Father calling us together was to announce a new plan of entry into Moria.

Earlier that day my father, Ongleth had talked alone with Dremurth, who had advised an alternative passage into Moria about which only dwarves had ever known. Its location had always been held in secrecy, although Dremurth felt warranted to reveal it given the dire situation of Middle Earth. The revelation had pleased Ongleth who, for most of his life, did not trust dwarves. Given the brave stories of Gimmley from the Fellowship and other dwarves dedicating their lives to the destruction of Sauron and safety and prosperity of Middle Earth, he had shed his bias. He saw in Dremurth and Axel, and many other dwarves, great warriors, of the kind he and elfinkind could now not do without. Indeed, he realized that the majority of the group which he now led, were dwarves. Furthermore, some of the burdensome equipment, which the commission had lugged all the way from Rivendell, could be parted with. As much as Dremurth drank, joked, and slurred his speech on occasion, Ongleth trusted Dremurth's guidance as the commission's navigator. In his eyes he saw wisdom, sincerity and steadfastness. He knew Dremurth would never give up.

The new entry chosen was known as the Jagged Rock of Kwalthorn. It did not require a climb as the Grimmstone Neck would have. More or less, Kwalthorn was a hidden cavernous orifice that lay behind and under a large jagged rock that lay on a mountainside, only miles from the infamous door where Frodo had uttered the word "friend" in elvish. Entry required a narrow, hands and knees crawl under the jagged rock first, for about one hundred feet in length, before it opened up enough to see, with lit torch, an opening into the mountainside.

About three miles before the commission had approached the Jagged Rock of Kwalthorn, they left their horses and now excessive mountain climbing supplies, skins and other large items that could not make it through the crawl, with three of the humans, who were given orders to care for the horses and guard the supplies in a well chosen hideout. It was a niche between two smaller mountains, water near, with trees for cover from around and above. They would be safe there thought Ongleth. Dremurth seconded. They were to wait till either the commission itself or ally with message from the commission returned, or one month's time, after which they could abandon the horses and stores and choose to go wherever they felt, except Moria, for if the commission did not return, that would mean disaster inside. Anthiala agreed, and blessed the three as the commission separated from them.

Before sunset, the commission, now numbering sixty, had reached the secret Jagged Rock of Kwalthorn, and within twenty minutes the last member had executed the initial crawl. All were inside. At last they were inside the Mines of Moria.

*****

You think about your past, and how close Sauron had come to gaining complete authority over Middle Earth. You realize that if you do not help, this undefined evil could threaten all that is good, like Sauron had, but this evil unfighted could win. You had already made your mind up, now you just had to wait and see what Elrond was going to say. The room was filled with silence as Elrond walked back in and sat down.

         "All of you who have already cowered down and decided not to help the fate of Middle Earth, please leave now, for I don't have the heart to speak nor see you." Elrond ordered. When the last word departed from his lips, not a soul moved. You were surprised, yet pleased to see that everyone was willing to help.
         "I had no doubt that many of you would help, but this many is beyond belief. Certainly this is a miracle." Elrond continued, "We have little or worthless knowledge of what excatly this undefined evil is hoping to achieve. And from there, we will get back in touch when we think we've all had enough information revealed to us. Then our strategy for attack will commence. Form groups of nine now. Only one group already has been decided, the Fellowship of The Ring will travel together, as they once did many years ago. Boromir is no longer with us, so one of you will travel in his place.          You felt a little out of place once more, untill you felt a little hand rest upon your shoulder. You turned around to find that it was Frodo. Kings and Queens before us? Imporant someone?

You take another look up into the endless boughs of branches.
121211111122.title: Clues

1212111111221.content:
Your eyes light up, and you take to your heels.
Running up the hills covered in roots and leaves, you stare up into the camoflagued abyss above you. Kings and Queens. Somewhere an important clue lies among those tress.
You turn around and see the elf and the man following you. You think about telling them to leave you to your thoughts for a moment. But what does it matter? They should know.

You climb further and further to a higher elevation. Finally you reach the place where the ground has ended. Your only choice is to climb the trees. You don't wait for your friends behind you. Instead you start climbing the trees, your bare feet able to feel the soft moss and bark of this tree. You feel a special connection with it. It matters to you.
Finally you reach the ruins of the first mysterious house in the trees. The old wood smells of dampness and rain. There are rotted papers and broken furnitures strewn all over the "house." You look below you. Legolas and Aragorn are catching up. Hurry. Before they get here.
You take a cautious from your branch to the floor. It seems all right. Looking around you see more than just trash. There are trinkets and charms, children's play things as well.
"I'm obviously not the first to have found this place," you think.
But something small and round catches your eye. It glimmers in this dusty floor. You pick it up and wipe the dust off of it. Before you get a good look at it though you hear the man and the elf approaching. You hide the trinket it your palm and await the arrival of your friends.

Until you hear a cracking noise....
1212111111221.title: Falling

12121111112211.content:
You fall and fall...screaming, you can hear your own voice as if you weren't the one screaming at all. Its amazing you havent hit any other branches yet, but then you're an elf. You get lucky.

Suddnely you hit the ground. Flat ground. You head smashes against your arm and you black out.
12121111112211.title: Dying

121211111122112.content:
The two men are back....staring towards the sky with a wild look in their eyes.
You can see their mouths moving, but frustratingly you can't hear what they are saying.
You've gotten a better look at the men before you. One is short and stocky, built like a hunter with a gruffy beard and a long scar right above the bridge of his nose. The other was taller, but still stocky. You are amazed by the fact he wears a full suit of armor, the heavy kind complete with a shield. He has a strong jaw and a thin-lipped serious mouth.
Suddenly the taller one looks in your direction. Can he see you? He's yelling now, his eyes locked on yours. They come rushing towards you....
121211111122112.title: Dreams

You are staring into the eyes of the most beautiful angel in the world.
"Please," you whisper, "I must tell them..."
"She's awake! Awake!" Legolas laughs and speaks quickly in Elvish. He's shaking and his face is whiter than usual.
"Leave her be," Aragorn answers and picks you gently up. He sets you on a horse. A sharp pain shoots through you neck to your head but you don't call out. You can't. Your mouth is too dry.
You feel yourself blacking out again, but you call on everything you know to keep you awake.
"They know.." you rasp.
"It's all right," Aragorn says gently, getting up behind you.
"It's not all right...they know."
"Save your strength, nothing is worth speaking still."
Is this a hint? You think he's trying to tell you to shut up.

You do. The pain is too much and you slink back on Aragorn. Please you think. Please let it not be too late.
You're an elf. You can't die from this one small fall. You can't....you black out again.

When you wake up you are staring into the face of....

You awaken..the pain is gone and the room is dark. It is obviously night and you find yourself looking into the face of the wise old wizard, Gandalf. He smiles at you and says nothing. You smile back. You are so glad to see him, yet you don't know why. You sit up and find that there is nothing wrong with you..not one bruise. Was it a dream?
"I cannot die from sickness nor age...but a fall?" you say, clearly perplexed.
Gandalf sits back and laughs. "You are not dead nor hurt. Not one scratch on you."
"But I fell didn't I?"
"Yes you fell. You fell out of the tree. Legolas and Aragorn said they saw you jump from the branches..."
"I did not jump! I fell through the floor."
This wiped the smile off Gandalf's face.
"The floor was perfectly intact," he says. "I believe you were fazed by something, maybe by the height and you threw yourself off the branch."
You get angry. "Threw myself? Doesnt that sound a bit ridiculous? I know I fell...." but you hear footsteps...

"Legolas?" you turn to your friend with worried eyes.
He gives you that look that says, don't talk about it. "Glad to see you're doing well," are his only words.

12121111122.content:
You awaken slowly, gradually returning to consciousness. You become aware of his voice first and allow it to draw you upward.

Landeis? Do you hear me? A pause. I can feel you awakening. Your mind is coming alive with music. Music and such beauty. You are truly beautiful, body and soul. That is a rare quality to find, even in elven women. It pains me to admit that we elves have fallen prey to some of the human world's vice. But you, you dear Landeis, give me hope that the elven people will not succumb. That even in the human world there is virtue and beauty.

You listen to the melodious beauty of his voice and feel a part of you that has been long hidden arising. You see him in your mind's eye, tall and strong with a noble stature and a honorable heart. He brings to mind no memories of the one who broke your heart. His name spills from your lips.

"Legolas?" You open your eyes and see him gently smiling down at you.

"At last. The beauty has awakened." In a rare unguarded moment, Legolas meets your gaze and you realize with a jolt that Legolas cares for you as deeply as you care for him. You begin to smile and you open your mouth to speak, when Gandalf's voice sounds.

"Legolas? Has she awakened yet?"

Legolas' eyes blank and you can see the impenetrable wall quickly go back up. He calls over his shoulder, "Yes she has." He glances at you as the door to the tent is pulled back and you know your expression matches his. Quickly you whisper that there is something you must tell him and he nods. You understand that you will talk later.

"Sir Gandalf." You greet the wizard with a deferential bow of your head.

"Oh nonsense." He gawfs. "There is no need for such formality here. Tell me lady, what befell you? All any of us know is that Legolas thought you were warning us to leave Lothlorien and we left in a very big hurry. I was not even able to finish my conversation with Celeborn and Galadriel. You've been out of it for a better part of the morning. Naturally we're all very curious. Especially Pippin and Merry. They do so dislike their meal schedules being interrupted."

You sense that beneath the twinkling eyes and jovial manner, there is a very keen curiosity. "If you will allow me to dress, I will address the Fellowship."

Frodo's voice pipes up from somewhere outside the tent. "Remember you are a part of OUR fellowship."

"I will be sure to remember." You assure him, exchanging smiles with Gandalf and Legolas.

The men exit the tent and you prepare to dress in your traveling clothes. You are shocked and a bit dismayed to discover that the only clothes the men thought to bring with are dresses, and formal dresses at that. You know that there is no way you can ride a horse or walk and hike in such finery. You are about to call out when you spot a piece of green fabric poking out from beneath your make-shift bed. You gently pull on it and out slips a beautiful dress done in the colors of the wood. It is loose and light, which will make it easy to maneuver in. You find sturdy walking boots to go along with it. As you slip the dress over your head you hear the soft crinkle of parchment paper and after looking, find a hidden pocket. Inside is a note that reads:

I felt that you would find this more comfortable and fitting to wear than the dresses that the men found for you. It is made of the same material as our cloaks and will help you to blend in. Frodo and Aragorn carry the rest of my gifts to you. Fight bravely dear sister. Our future rests in your hands.
~Galadriel


You straighten your shoulders and gladly accept the burden Galadriel has placed upon them. You finish lacing up your boots and exit the tent. Going outside, a vision greets your eye. The Fellowship has traveled far in the night, spurred on by Legolas's worry and your warning. You stand at the edge of a gigantic lake, the likes of which you have never seen before. Pippin clears his throat impatiently and you turn to your group mates with a smile.

"I am sure you are all wondering what has brought you so far from Lothlorien so quickly. Last night, as I was telling Aragorn of a vision I had had, a strange sensation gripped me. It seemed that my memory was failing me and the more I struggled to reclaim it, the further it slid from my grasp. As you know, we elves are known for our long and excellent memories. It did not make sense to me. I fought so long and the force fighting me was so strong that I began to lose consciousness. The effort it required to make me submit was so great that the force had to allow me entry into it's mind. As it did, I realized that the force knew of us, knew of our mission and even knew of our arrival in Lothlorien. I sensed that it was sending something after us, some enormous evil that would gravely endanger all of Lothlorien."

"Wait." Pippin interrupts. "So you're telling me, that we left them...so that this thing can come kill us?!?!"

"Yes." You nod.

Merry throws his hands up in the air. "Great. Just great!"

"We all knew there would be danger in helping protect Middle Earth once again." Sam answers stoutly. "No use complainin' about it."

"So you've had contact with the threat." Gandalf murmurs. He looks at you appraisingly. "Do you think you could give us any more information about him...her...it?"

"Nothing more than I have told you already. To come in contact with a mind that corrupt..." You trail off and meet Gandalf's gaze unflinchingly. "You can not understand, Sir Gandalf, what a horror that is for one such as I. To be inside the mind of a thing that is wholly and completely evil especially when that thing is also manipulative is extremely dangerous for a elf. I could have turned without the slightest hesitation if I had been in more intimate contact with it."

"Intimate contact?" Gandalf queries.

"The meeting of the minds is an intimate affair Gandalf, especially for the elves. You know that." Legolas says, his expression one of subtle disbelief. "Why do you press her so?"

Gandalf abruptly breaks eye contact with you. "No reason. No reason." He mumbles as he turns away.

"I know why." You state softly. The others turn to you in surprise, Aragorn and Legolas with resignation. "You wish to use me, do you not Sir Gandalf? As bait."

Pipin, Merry and Sam look from you to Gandalf with confused expressions on their faces. They do not understand why you, who have been so kind to them are being so hostile towards Gandalf, who is their friend. Frodo's eyes are heavy with understanding. He, at least, understands that Gandalf wishes to use you in much the same way he himself was used. Gimli, on watch, is too far away to understand what is being said. Aragorn and Legolas send a silent message and Legolas moves toward you while Aragorn moves toward Gandolf.

"Come old friend." Aragorn murmurs to Gandalf. "Let us go and talk of what Celeborn and Galadriel had to say." He pulls Gandalf toward the woods.

Legolas comes to your side and whispers softly in Elven, "Come dear heart. We have much to talk about."

As you turn toward him, it seems that Gandalf is possessed by some evil spirit. He breaks free of Aragorn and runs toward you. He shouts at you, "You haven't seen it! You know not of what it is capable! It will kill us all if we can't stop it!! YOU KNOW NOT!" He roars as he flies at you swinging his staff in a wide arc.

You duck and side-step in the same motion, your reflexes taking over. The hobbits shout in horror and Gimli comes rushing through the trees, brandishing his axe, certain the group is under attack. Legolas and Aragorn are both running toward Gandalf when everything seems to freeze.

You see again the vision that the Mirror revealed to you, but this time the girl reaches her arms out to you and cries the word, "Mama." You hear a heinous chuckle and your world fades to black as your daughter is tore from your arms.

You awake to Aragorn's concerned face. "Landeis how do you feel?" He asks as he helps you sit up.

"Like I was hit with something." You groan, lightly rubbing a sore spot on your scull. "Did Gandalf strike me?"

Aragorn chuckles grimly. "He managed to get in a lucky swing. Legolas about killed him as you crumpled to the ground. It took all of us to pull him off. The hobbits are watching him now, while Gimli keeps watch over Gandalf."

You nod slowly. "What is happening to us Estel?"

"I know not." Aragorn's eyes are bleak as he gazes out over the lake. "Perhaps we are not fated to once again save Middle Earth."

"If not us, then who?"

Even the smallest person can change the course of the future...

         Remember this as you are offered a chance to make a difference to fight the ongoing evil in Middle Earth. You will have the choice of making your own group, or you will be offered the chance to accompany those from the Fellowship of The Ring, that was formed at the Council of Elrond, but you will meet many others as well.
         Think out your decisions wisely, and be sure you are making the right choice, because you can never go back. Sauron may have been defeated and the One Ring destroyed, but evil still lurks in Middle Earth. Will your presence help or harm what is done? Can you really change the course of the future? Are you truly willing and ready to find out?
         You say you are? Well then, begin your journey as you travel to the Rivendell, one of the most beautiful elven cities. There you will be faced with some of your first decisions. Whom shall you accompany first? Where do you go from there? Step quickly now, you haven't a moment to waste.
